[[File:Hunter Museum Label.jpg|thumb|Every object in galleries has a label where you'll find that object's accession number. ]] In [[library|libraries]], [[art gallery|art galleries]], [[museum]]s and [[archive]]s, an '''accession number''' is a unique identifier assigned to, and achieving initial control of, each acquisition. Assignment of accession numbers typically occurs at the point of accessioning or cataloging. The term is something of a misnomer, because the form accession numbers take is often alpha-numeric.<ref name="Witt">Witt, B.S., Whittfield, J.C., Stepansky, A.J. (2012) ''Pastperfect software for museum collections: Version 5 users guide.'' Retrieved from http://museumsoftware.com/v5userguide.html</ref>
If an item is removed from the collection, its number is usually not reused for new items.
In libraries, this numbering system is usually in addition to the [[library classification]] number (or alphanumeric code) and to the [[ISBN]] or International Standard Book Number assigned by [[publisher]]s.
Accession numbers are also used in [[botany]], by institutions with living collections like [[arboretum|arboreta]], [[botanic garden]]s, etc., to identify plants or groups of plants that are of the same [[taxon]], are of the same [[Propagule|propagule type]] (or treatment), were received from the same source, were received at the same time.<ref name="Glasnevin">Jebb, Matthew (1998) ''Cataloguing and Record keeping for Plant Collections'' Retrieved from http://www.botanicgardens.ie/educ/accnosho.pdf</ref> [[Herbarium|Herbaria]] and other botanic institutions collecting non living material also use accession numbers.{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}}
An accession number may include the year acquired, sometimes the full date (as at the [[British Museum]]), and a sequential number separated by a period.<ref name="Witt" /> In addition, departments or art classifications within the collection or museum may reserve sections of numbers. For example, objects identified by the numbers 11.000 through 11.999 may indicate objects obtained by the museum in 1911; the first 300 numbers might be used to indicate American art, while the next fifty (11.301–350) might be used for [[African art]]. In some cases, they also include letters and other punctuation, such as commas, hyphens or slashes.<ref>Reitz, J.M. (2004) ''Dictionary for library and information science.'' Libraries Unlimited. p. 6</ref>
In older institutions, simpler numbering systems are sometimes maintained alongside, or incorporated within, newer systems. Where the objects are unique, institutions normally need to retain the original number in some form as it will have been used in old references that are still of use in scholarship. In particular, collections of [[manuscripts]] use the prefix "MS", and many well known manuscripts are known by their old MS numbers, often incorporating a prefix for a particular collection within a library. These collections may be divided by former owners, as with several [[British Library]] [[:Category:British Library collections|"closed" collections]], or by language, as with [[Froissart of Louis of Gruuthuse (BnF Fr 2643-6)|Froissart of Louis of Gruuthuse (BnF MS Fr. 2643-6)]], indicating a two volume manuscript in French at the {{lang|fr|[[Bibliothèque nationale de France]]}}.
== See also == * [[Universally unique identifier]] * [[Library of Congress Control Number]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} {{good article}} {{speciesbox | name = Atlantic blue marlin | image = Atlantic blue marlin.jpg | image_caption = Male | status = VU | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref name=IUCN>{{Cite journal | author = Collette, B. | author2 = Acero, A. | author3 = Amorim, A.F. | author4 = Boustany, A. | author5 = Canales Ramirez, C. | author6 = Cardenas, G. | author7 = Carpenter, K.E. | author8 = de Oliveira Leite Jr., N. | author9 = Di Natale, A. | author10 = Die, D. | display-authors = etal | title = ''Makaira nigricans'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2011 | page = e.T170314A6743776 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2011 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/170314/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2011-2.RLTS.T170314A6743776.en | access-date = 25 December 2017}}</ref> | genus = Makaira | species = nigricans | authority = [[Bernard Germain de Lacépède|Lacépède]], 1802 | range_map = Makaira nigricans Range Map.svg | range_map_caption = The range of the Atlantic blue marlin | synonyms = See below }} The '''Atlantic blue marlin''' (''Makaira nigricans'') is a species of [[marlin]] endemic to the Atlantic Ocean. It is closely related to, and usually considered conspecific with, the [[Indo-Pacific blue marlin]], then simply called blue marlin. Some authorities still consider both species distinct.
The Atlantic blue marlin (hereafter, blue marlin) feeds on a wide variety of organisms near the surface. It uses its bill to stun, injure, or kill while knifing through a school of fish or other prey, then returns to eat the injured or stunned fish. Marlin is a popular [[game fish]]. The relatively high fat content of its meat makes it commercially valuable in certain markets. It is the national fish of the [[The Bahamas|Commonwealth of the Bahamas]] and is featured on its coat of arms.
Blue marlin are distributed throughout the tropical and subtropical waters of the [[Atlantic Ocean]]. A [[maritime geography|bluewater]] fish that spends the majority of its life in the open sea far from land,<ref name=zoo> {{citation |url=http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/fish/blue-marlin.html |publisher= National Geographic |title=Blue Marlin |accessdate=2008-11-11 }}.</ref> the blue marlin preys on a wide variety of marine organisms, mostly near the surface, often using its bill to stun or injure its prey.
Females can grow up to four times the weight of males. The maximum published weight is {{convert|818|kg|lb|abbr=on}} and length {{convert|5|m|ft|1|abbr=on}}.<ref name=fishbase>{{FishBase species | genus = Makaira | species = nigricans | month = August| year = 2013}}</ref>
Adult blue marlin have few predators apart from killer whales, sharks, and humans. They are sought after as a highly prized game fish by anglers and are taken by commercial fishermen, both as a directed catch and as bycatch in major industrial tuna fisheries. Blue marlin are currently considered a threatened species by the IUCN due to [[overfishing]] <ref name=IUCN/>, particularly in the international waters off the coast of Portugal where they migrate to breed in the June/July months.{{cn|date=July 2018}}
Some other historic English names for the blue marlin are '''Cuban black marlin''', '''ocean gar''', and '''ocean guard'''.<ref name=marlin> {{citation |url=http://www.flmnh.ufl.edu/fish/Gallery/Descript/BlueMarlin/BlueMarlin.html |publisher=Florida Museum of Natural History |title=Atlantic Blue Marlin |accessdate=2009-01-29 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090126222448/http://flmnh.ufl.edu/fish/Gallery/Descript/BlueMarlin/BlueMarlin.html| archivedate= 26 January 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Taxonomy and naming== The blue marlin is placed in the genus ''Makaira''. This name is derived from the Greek word ''machaira'', meaning "a short sword or bent dagger", and the Latin ''machaera'', "sword".<ref> {{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3lCQPKCUUf4C&pg=PA1576&lpg=PA1576&dq=Greek+etymology+of+machaera |publisher=CRC |title=CRC World Dictionary of Plant Names |accessdate=2009-01-29 |isbn=978-0-8493-2677-6 |author1=Quattrocchi, Umberto |year=2000 }}</ref><ref> {{citation |url = http://www.indo-european.nl/cgi-bin/response.cgi?root=leiden&morpho=0&basename=\data\ie\ohg&first=2061 |publisher = Koebler |title = Old High German Etymological Database (Koebler) |accessdate = 2009-02-15 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The [[specific name (zoology)|specific epithet]] ''nigricans'' is Latin for "becoming black".<ref> {{citation |doi=10.2307/3762182 |url=http://www.mycologia.org/cgi/content/full/96/3/650 |publisher=Mycologia |title=New Species of Clavulina from Guyana |accessdate=2009-02-07 |journal=Mycologia |volume=96 |issue=3 |pages=650–657 |author1=Thacker, Jason R. |author2=Henkel, Terry W |date=1 May 2004 |jstor=3762182 |pmid=21148885 }}</ref> The blue marlin is part of the [[billfish]] family [[Istiophoridae]] and is in the [[perch]]-like order [[Perciformes]]. In addition, it is in the suborder Xiphioidei and is a member of the subclass [[Neopterygii]], which means "new wings". It is also in the class of [[Actinopterygii]], which includes ray-finned fishes and spiny-rayed fishes, and the superclass [[Osteichthyes]], which includes all of the bony fishes.<ref name=VT> {{citation |url=http://www.fishbase.org/Summary/SpeciesSummary.php?id=216 |publisher= FishBase |title=Makaira nigricans Atlantic blue marlin |accessdate=2008-11-15 }}</ref><ref name=million> {{citation |url = http://www.cbif.gc.ca/pls/itisca/taxastep?king=every&p_action=containing&taxa=Makaira+nigricans |publisher = ITIS |title = Scientific Name: ''Makaira nigricans'' Lacepède, 1802 |accessdate = 2009-01-25 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140907080450/http://www.cbif.gc.ca/pls/itisca/taxastep?king=every&p_action=containing&taxa=Makaira+nigricans |archivedate = 7 September 2014 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
The classification of the Atlantic blue marlin (''M. nigricans'') and the [[Indo-Pacific blue marlin]] (''M. mazara'') as separate species is under debate. Genetic data suggest, although the two groups are isolated from each other, they are both the same species, with the only genetic exchange occurring when Indo-Pacific blue marlin migrate to and contribute genes to the Atlantic population.<ref> {{citation |url=http://jhered.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/89/5/427 |title= Molecular Insights Into the Population Structures of Cosmopolitan Marine Fishes |author=Graves, J. E. |year=1998 |journal=Journal of Heredity |volume=89 |issue=5 |pages=427–437 |doi=10.1093/jhered/89.5.427 }}, see page 429.</ref> A separate study by V. P. Buonaccorsi, J. R. Mcdowell, and Graves indicated that both Indo-Pacific and Atlantic show "striking [[phylogeographic]] partitioning" of [[mitochondrial]] and [[Microsatellite (genetics)|microsatellite]] [[Locus (genetics)|loci]].<ref> {{citation |url = http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/links/doi/10.1046%2Fj.1365-294X.2001.01270.x |archive-url = https://archive.is/20120724033824/http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/links/doi/10.1046/j.1365-294X.2001.01270.x |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2012-07-24 |title = Reconciling patterns of inter-ocean molecular variance from four classes of molecular markers in blue marlin (Makaira nigricans) |author = Buonaccorsi, V. P. |author2 = Mcdowell, J. R. |author3 = Graves, J. E. |last-author-amp = yes |year = 2001 |journal = Molecular Ecology |volume = 10 |issue = 5 |pages = 1179–1196 |doi = 10.1046/j.1365-294X.2001.01270.x |pmid = 11380876 }}.</ref>
===Synonyms=== Synonyms of ''M. nigricans'' are:<ref name=fishbase/> {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * ''Maikaira nigricans (sic)'' <small>Lacepède, 1802</small> * ''Makaira nigricans nigricans'' <small>Lacepède, 1802</small> * ''Xiphias ensis'' <small>Lacepède, 1800</small> (ambiguous) * ''Makaira ensis'' <small>(Lacepède, 1800)</small> (ambiguous) * ''Tetrapturus herschelii'' <small>J. E. Gray, 1838</small> * ''Histiophorus herschelii'' <small>(J. E. Gray, 1838)</small> * ''Makaira herschelii'' <small>(J. E. Gray, 1838)</small> * ''Tetrapturus amplus'' <small>Poey, 1860</small> * ''Makaira ampla'' <small>(Poey, 1860)</small> * ''Makaira ampla ampla'' <small>(Poey, 1860)</small> * ''Makaira nigricans ampla'' <small>(Poey, 1860)</small> * ''Makaira bermudae'' <small>Mowbray, 1931</small> * ''Orthocraeros bermudae'' <small>(Mowbray, 1931)</small> * ''Eumakaira nigra'' <small>Hirasaka & H. Nakamura, 1947</small> * ''Makaira nigra'' <small>(Hirasaka & H. Nakamura, 1947)</small> * ''Makaira perezi'' <small>F. de Buen, 1950</small> * ''Istiompax howardi'' <small>Whitley, 1954</small> {{div col end}}
==Description==
[[File:Blue marlin skeleton.jpg|thumb|Skeleton in museum|Intact fish skeleton at the [[North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences]]]] The biggest females are more than four times as heavy as the biggest males, which rarely exceed {{convert|160|kg|lb|abbr=on}} in weight.<ref name=ummz>{{citation |url=http://animaldiversity.ummz.umich.edu/site/accounts/information/Makaira_nigricans.html |publisher= Animal diversity web |title=Makaira nigricans |accessdate=2008-10-13 }}.</ref> The longest females can reach a length of {{convert|5|m|ft|abbr=on}} with the bill, from eye to tip, constituting about 20% of the total body length.
Body mass in the largest female specimens has been reported from {{convert|540|to|820|kg|lb|abbr=on}}, depending on the source (few large specimens are scientifically verified).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://marinebio.org/species.asp?id=386 |title=Blue Marlins, Makaira nigricans at |publisher=Marinebio.org |date= |accessdate=2012-06-28}}</ref> The largest blue marlin caught by IGFA angling rules is from Vitoria, Brazil, which weighed {{convert|1402|lb|kg|abbr=on}}.;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flmnh.ufl.edu/fish/gallery/descript/bluemarlin/bluemarlin.html |title=FLMNH Ichthyology Department: Blue Marlin |publisher=Flmnh.ufl.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-06-28}}</ref> fishermen often refer to individual marlins that reach or exceed 1,000 pounds as "granders".
Both sexes have 24 [[vertebra]]e, of which 11 are precaudal and 13 are caudal.<ref name=yummy> {{citation |url=ftp://ftp.fao.org/docrep/fao/009/ac480e/AC480E06.pdf |publisher= FAO Species Identification and Data Programme |title=Vol. 5. Billfishes of the World |accessdate=2008-11-11 }}.</ref>
The marlin has two [[dorsal fin]]s and two [[anal fin]]s. The fins are supported by bony spines known as [[Actinopterygii|rays]]. Its first dorsal fin has 39 to 43 rays from front to back.<ref name="yummy"/> Its second dorsal fin has six or seven rays.<ref name="yummy"/> Its first anal fin, which is similar in shape and size to the second dorsal fin, has 13 to 16 rays,<ref name="yummy"/> and the second anal fin has six or seven rays.<ref name="yummy"/> The pectoral fins, which have 19 to 22 rays,<ref name="yummy"/> are long and narrow and can be drawn in to the sides of the body. The [[pelvic fin]]s are shorter than the pectorals, have a poorly developed membrane, and are depressible into ventral grooves. Its first anal fin, along with its [[pectoral fin|pectoral]] and [[caudal fin]]s, can be folded into grooves. This [[Streamlines, streaklines, and pathlines|streamlines]] the fish and thereby reduces [[drag (physics)|drag]].
Blue marlin, like other billfish, can rapidly change color, an effect created by pigment-containing [[iridophore]]s and light-reflecting skin cells.<ref> {{citation |url=http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/355/1401/1253.full.pdf+html?sid=815eb949-fc5c-4343-ac03-e5ce6af6c2aa |publisher= The Royal Society |title=Colour vision in billfish |accessdate=2008-01-02 |doi=10.1098/rstb.2000.0678 |year=2000 |author1=Fritsches, Kerstin A. |author2=Partridge, Julian C. |author3=Pettigrew, John D. |author4=Marshall, N. Justin |journal=[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B]] |volume=355 |pages=1253–6 |pmid=11079409 |issue=1401 |pmc=1692849 }}</ref>
Most often, however, the body is blue-black on top with a silvery white underside. It has about 15 rows of pale, cobalt-colored stripes, each of which has round dots and/or thin bars, located on both sides of the fish.<ref name="yummy"/> The first dorsal fin membrane is dark blue or almost black and has no dots or marks. Other fins are normally brownish-black, sometimes with a hint of dark blue. The bases of the first and second anal fins have a hint of silvery white.
The body is covered with thick, bony, elongated scales that have one, two, or three posterior points, with one being the most common form.<ref name="yummy"/>
The bill is long and stout. Both the jaws and the palatines (the roof of the mouth) are covered with small, file-like teeth. The [[lateral line|lateral line system]] is a group of [[lateral line|neuromasts]] rooted in lateral line canals that can sense weak water motions and large changes in pressure.<ref> {{citation |url=http://www.jacobs-university.de/news/events/08232/ |publisher= Jacobs University |title=The lateral line system of fish: structure, function and behavioral relevance |accessdate=2009-02-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080327152504/http://www.jacobs-university.de/news/events/08232/ |archivedate = 27 March 2008}}</ref> It has the appearance of a net.<ref name=mummy> {{citation |url=http://marinebio.org/species.asp?id=386 |publisher= MarineBio |title= Makaira nigricans Blue Marlin |accessdate=2009-01-25 }}</ref> It is obvious in immature specimens but unclear in adults, becoming progressively embedded in the skin.<ref name=yummy/> The anus is just in front of the origin of the first anal fin.
==Range and migration==
Blue marlin are found year-round in tropical oceanic waters of the Atlantic. The range expands into temperate waters of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres during the warmer months and contracts towards the Equator during colder months.<ref> {{citation |url = http://www.sefsc.noaa.gov/PDFdocs/Luckhurst.et.al.Bull.Mar.Sci.2006.BUM.pdf |format = PDF |last1 = Luckhurst |first1 = Brian E. |last2 = Prince |first2 = Eric D. |last3 = Llopiz |first3 = Joel K. |last4 = Snodgrass |first4 = Derke |last5 = Brothers |first5 = Edward B. |title = Evidence Of Blue Marlin (''Makaira nigricans'') spawning in Bermuda waters and elevated mercury levels in large specimens |journal = Bulletin of Marine Science |volume = 79 |issue = 3 |pages = 691–704 |publisher = Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science of the University of Miami |location = USA |year = 2006 |accessdate = 11 February 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090507070827/http://www.sefsc.noaa.gov/PDFdocs/Luckhurst.et.al.Bull.Mar.Sci.2006.BUM.pdf |archivedate = 7 May 2009 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Warm currents such as the [[Gulf Stream]] in the western Atlantic have a major influence on their seasonal distribution.
The blue marlin's latitudinal range extends from about [[45th parallel north|45°N]] to about 35°S. It is less abundant in the eastern Atlantic, where it mostly occurs off Africa between the latitudes of 25°N and 25°S. The largest numbers are usually found in waters warmer than 24 °C (75 °F), but blue marlin have been found at surface water temperatures as high as 30.5 °C (86.9 °F) and as low as 21.7 °C (71.1 °F).<ref name=blue> {{citation |url=https://archive.org/details/proceedingsofint03inte |format=PDF|publisher=NOAA Department of Commerce |title=Proceedings of the International Billfish Symposium |accessdate=2008-11-15 }}</ref>
Tagging studies, using conventional "spaghetti" tags, and more recently [[Pop-up satellite archival tag|pop-up satellite tags]], have given researchers a glimpse into blue marlin migration patterns and habits. Recaptures of tagged fish have shown multiple movements between the [[Caribbean]] Islands and [[Venezuela]] and the [[Bahamas]], as well as between the Caribbean [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands]] and West Africa, and interocean travel. Most notably, a blue marlin tagged off the coast of Delaware was recovered near the island of Mauritius off the southeast coast of Africa in the Indian Ocean – a voyage of 9,254 miles.<ref name="tunaresearch.org">http://www.tunaresearch.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=111&Itemid=232</ref> Several fish have been recaptured in the same general area where they were tagged, implying reverse migration after/over several years, but the data are insufficient to accurately determine seasonality.<ref> {{citation |url=http://spo.nmfs.noaa.gov/mfr522/mfr5223.pdf |format=PDF|publisher=NMFS CooperativeGameFish Tagging Program |title=Blue Marlin, Makaira nigricans, Movements in the Western North Atlantic Ocean: Results of a Cooperative Game Fish Tagging Program, 1954–88 |accessdate=2008-11-17 }}</ref>
== Predators and parasites == Once blue marlin reach maturity, they have few predators, with the most important probably being large pelagic sharks such as the [[shortfin mako]] and [[great white shark]].<ref name=white> {{citation |url=http://zipcodezoo.com/Animals/M/Makaira_nigricans/Default.asp |publisher=Zipcode Zoo |title=Makaira nigricans (Atlantic Blue Marlin) |accessdate=2008-11-18 }}</ref>
Blue marlin have many parasites, including from these groups: [[Digenea]] (flukes), Didymozoidea (tissue flukes), [[Monogenea]] (gillworms), [[Cestoda]] (tapeworms), [[Nematoda]] (roundworms), [[Acanthocephala]] (spiny-headed worms), [[copepods]], [[barnacle]]s, and [[cookiecutter shark]]s.
==Lifecycle==
'''Growth and maturity'''
Atlantic blue marlin reach [[sexual maturity]] at the age of two to four years. Males reach sexual maturity at a weight of {{convert|35|-|44|kg|lb|abbr=on}} and females at {{convert|47|-|61|kg|lb|abbr=on}}.<ref> {{citation |url=http://www.flmnh.ufl.edu/fish/Gallery/Descript/BlueMarlin/BlueMarlin.html |publisher=ICCAT |title=Prelimary Results on Reproductive Biology of Blue Marlin, ''Makaira Nigricans'' (LACÉPÈDE, 1803) in the Tropical Western Atlantic Ocean |accessdate=2009-01-20 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090126222448/http://flmnh.ufl.edu/fish/Gallery/Descript/BlueMarlin/BlueMarlin.html| archivedate= 26 January 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Blue marlin breed in late summer and fall. Females may spawn as many as four times in one season. They often release over seven million [[Egg (biology)|eggs]] at once, each about {{convert|1|mm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter. Few reach sexual maturity. The [[planktonic]] young drift freely in the ocean's [[pelagic zone]]. Larvae inhabit the west central Atlantic off [[Georgia (U.S. State)|Georgia]], [[North Carolina]], [[Florida]], [[Jamaica]], [[Bahamas]], the [[Dominican Republic]], and [[Puerto Rico]], and also the southwest Atlantic off [[Brazil]].<ref name=ummz/> The larvae may grow as much as {{convert|16|mm|in|abbr=on}} in a day.<ref name=ummz/> On their sides and [[dorsum (biology)|dorsal surface]]s, they are blue-black in color, while [[ventral]]ly they are white. Both the caudal fin and the [[caudal peduncle]] (the narrow part of the fish's body to which the [[Adipose fin|caudal or tail fin]] is attached) are clear. Two iridescent blue patches occur on the head, and some individuals have darker spots on their backs. In adolescents, the first dorsal fin is large and concave, gradually reducing in proportion to body size with continued growth.<ref name="marlin"/> Males may live for 18 years, and females up to 27.
'''Diet and feeding'''
The [[Ichthyoplankton|larvae]] feed upon a variety of [[zooplankton]] along with drifting fish eggs and other larvae. They progress to feeding on a wide range of fishes, particularly scombrids, such as [[mackerel]] and [[tuna]], [[squid]], and especially near oceanic islands and [[coral reef]]s, on juvenile inshore fish. Studies of stomach contents have found that smaller schooling scombrids such as [[frigate mackerel]], [[bullet tuna]], and [[skipjack tuna]] make up a substantial proportion of their diet. Squid and deep-sea fishes such as [[pomfret]] and [[snake mackerel]] are also important prey items in certain areas. Blue marlin have been recorded to take prey as large as [[white marlin]], as well as [[yellowfin tuna|yellowfin]] and [[bigeye tuna]] in the 100-lb range. Conversely, they are also capable of feeding on small but numerous prey such as [[filefish]] and [[snipefish]].
Scientists and fishermen have long debated the extent to which blue marlin and other billfish use their elongated upper jaw in feeding. A 2007 Japanese study of stomach contents of fish captured in a commercial trolling fishery found that 130 undigested prey items obtained from 227 blue marlin had spearing, slashing, and other injuries that were judged to have been inflicted by the bill.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Shimose | first1 = T. | last2 = Yokawa | first2 = K. | last3 = Saito | first3 = H. | last4 = Tachihara | first4 = K. | title = Evidence for use of the bill by blue marlin, ''Makaira nigricans'', during feeding | doi = 10.1007/s10228-007-0419-x | journal = Ichthyological Research | volume = 54 | issue = 4 | pages = 420–422| year = 2007 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>
'''Bioaccumulation'''
[[Heavy metals]] have been known to accumulate in the Atlantic blue marlin, a process known as [[bioaccumulation]]. In 2017, the [[Texas Parks and Wildlife Department]] issued a consumption advisory for all blue marlin caught along the coast of Texas based on the presence of [[Mercury (element)|mercury]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://tpwd.texas.gov/regulations/outdoor-annual/fishing/general-rules-regulations/fish-consumption-bans-and-advisories |title=Fish Consumption Bans and Advisories |website=Texas Parks and Wildlife Department |access-date=2017-11-15}}</ref>
==Economic importance== [[File:Makaira nigricans meat.JPG|thumb|An 8-oz (230-g) marlin filet|alt=Approximately triangular piece of pink-to-red fish]]
=== Commercial fishery ===
Marlin has commercial value throughout the world, with landings totalling 3,064 metric tons in 2000.<ref name=ummz/> It is particularly valued in Japan for [[sashimi]].<ref name=ummz/> Blue marlin meat is sometimes smoked and sold by roadside vendors.
Blue marlin are often caught as [[bycatch]] in tuna [[longline fisheries]].
=== Recreational fishery ===
Sport fishermen first encountered blue marlin in the Bahamas in the 1920s and early 1930s, when pioneering big-game fishermen such as Van Campen Heilner and [[S. Kip Farrington]] began exploring the waters offshore of Bimini and Cat Cay. Since then, blue marlin have been renowned as one of the world's greatest game fishes. The sportfishing pursuit of marlin and other billfish has developed into a multimillion dollar industry that includes hundreds of companies and thousands of jobs for boat operators, boat builders, [[marina]]s, dealerships, and [[fishing tackle]] manufacturers and dealers.
The most established sport fisheries for blue marlin are found along the eastern seaboard and the [[Gulf Coast]] of the United States, Bermuda, the Bahamas, and several other Caribbean islands (notably St Thomas and [[Puerto Rico]]). Recreational fishing for blue marlin also takes place in [[Hawaii]], Brazil, [[Venezuela]], and the Atlantic coast of [[Mexico]], particularly the [[Yucatan]] peninsula. In the eastern Atlantic, blue marlin sport fisheries exist from the [[Algarve]] coast of [[Portugal]] in the north to [[Angola]] in the south and include the islands of the [[Azores]], [[Canary Islands|Canaries]], [[Cape Verde]], [[Madeira]], and [[Ascension Island]].
The [[IGFA|International Game Fish Association]] all-tackle world record for blue marlin currently stands at 1,402 lb 2 oz (636 kg).<ref name="marlin"/> This fish was captured in Vitoria, Brazil.
== Conservation == The blue marlin is under intense pressure from longline fishing. In the Caribbean region alone, Japanese and Cuban fishermen annually take over a thousand tons. All vessels within {{convert|200|mi|km|abbr=on}} of the U.S. coastline are required to release any [[billfish]] caught. However, the survival rate of released fish is low because of damage during capture.<ref name="marlin"/>
''Makaira nigricans'' is listed as a threatened species by the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]].<ref name=IUCN/> In 2010, [[Greenpeace International]] added the blue marlin to its seafood red list. <!-- "The Greenpeace International seafood red list is a list of fish that are commonly sold in supermarkets around the world, and which have a very high risk of being sourced from unsustainable fisheries." --><ref>[http://www.greenpeace.org/international/seafood/red-list-of-species Greenpeace International Seafood Red list] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100205030730/http://www.greenpeace.org/international/seafood/red-list-of-species |date=5 February 2010 }}</ref>
Sport fishermen have been at the forefront of efforts to conserve blue marlin populations. The initial efforts to develop electronic tags for tracking highly migratory fish were carried out on marlin in Hawaii, in collaboration with anglers in the Hawaiian International Billfish Tournament.<ref name="tunaresearch.org"/>
== In popular culture == [[File:Hemingway and Marlins.jpg|right|thumb|Ernest Hemingway with caught blue marlin]] Both Zane Grey and [[Ernest Hemingway]], who fished for blue marlin off the Florida Keys, the Bahamas, and most famously in Cuba, wrote extensively about their pursuit.
In Hemingway's novella ''[[The Old Man and the Sea]]'', a fisherman named Santiago battles a blue marlin for three days off the coast of Cuba.<ref name="zoo" /><ref> {{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1ZkDP6B9N6gC&pg=PA27&lpg=PA27&dq=blue+marlin+in+old+man+and+the+sea |publisher=The Greenwood Press |title=Understanding The Old Man and the Sea |accessdate=2008-11-17 |isbn=978-0-313-31631-9 |author1=Valenti, Patricia Dunlavy |year=2002 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of national animals]] *[[Marlin fishing]]

page.title: Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox military memorial | name = ''Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red'' | native_name = | native_name_lang = | body = United Kingdom | image = File:Blood Swept Lands And Seas Of Red 9 Aug 2014.JPG | caption = | commemorates = the [[centenary of the outbreak of World War I]] | use_dates = | established = {{start date|2014|7|17|df=yes}} | unveiled = {{end date|2014|11|11|df=yes}} | coordinates = {{coord|51.50912|-0.07528|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title, inline}} | location = moat at the [[Tower of London]] | nearest_town = | designer = [[Paul Cummins]]
[[Tom Piper]] | total_burials = | unknowns = | commemorated = 888,246 by ceramic poppies | by_country = | by_war = | inscription = | embedded = | findagrave = | source = Tower of London Remembers{{cite web|title=Tower of London Remembers|url=http://www.hrp.org.uk/TowerOfLondon/poppies|website=Historic Royal Palaces|accessdate=25 May 2015}} }} '''''Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red''''' was a public art installation created in the [[moat]] of the [[Tower of London]], England, between July and November 2014. It commemorated the [[centenary of the outbreak of World War I]] and consisted of 888,246 [[ceramic]] red [[Papaver rhoeas|poppies]], each intended to represent one British or Colonial serviceman killed in the War. The ceramic artist was [[Paul Cummins]], with conceptual design by the stage designer [[Tom Piper]].[http://poppies.hrp.org.uk/about-the-installation "About the installation"], Tower of London website. Retrieved 17 October 2014 The work's title was taken from the first line of a poem by an [[War poet|unknown soldier in World War I]]. ==Background== The work's title came from a poem discovered by Cummins and was used by Piper as the inspiration for his conceptual design. It was written by an unknown World War I soldier from [[Derbyshire]], who joined up in the early days of the war and died in at the Front of the First World War. The poem begins: "The blood swept lands and seas of red,/ Where angels dareSome sources give "... fear to tread ..." to tread / ... ".[https://www.ssafa.org.uk/get-involved/donate/wills/will-of-an-unnamed-soldier/ "The Will of an unnamed soldier"], SSAFA website (contains full text of poem). Retrieved 9 April 2015 The poem was contained in the soldier's unsigned [[will and testament|will]], found by Cummins among old records in [[Chesterfield]], Derbyshire.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/07/tower-london-moat-filled-ceramic-poppies-ww1-dead "Poppies to fill Tower of London moat in first world war commemoration"], ''The Guardian'', 7 May 2014. The work was created by Paul Cummins Ceramics in conjunction with Historic Royal Palaces to be displayed in the moat of the Tower of London, which was used in the early days of the war as a training ground for [[City of London]] workers who had enlisted to fight – the "[[Stockbrokers' Battalion]]". ==Form== The work consisted of a sea of [[ceramic]] red [[Papaver rhoeas|poppies]], in a design which appeared to flow out of the Tower itself and ripple across the moat. There were a series of designed elements which added drama, height and movement to the installation: the "Weeping Window" flowing out of a window in Legge's Mount in the West Moat, (which became the iconic image), "Over the Top", a cascade of poppies down the wall on the wharf side of the moat and the "Wave", a free-standing twisted metal sculpture covered in poppies which curled over the main causeway into the Tower. The ceramic poppies were individually hand-made at Cummins's ceramics works in Derbyshire and at Johnson Tiles in [[Tunstall, Staffordshire|Tunstall]], Stoke-on-Trent.[http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Campaign-launched-bring-Tower-London-poppies/story-25695953-detail/story.html "Campaign launched to bring the Tower of London poppies to Stoke-on-Trent"], ''The Sentinel'', 12 December 2014.[http://www.johnson-tiles.com/blog/2014/11/johnson-tiles-helps-poppies-bloom-tower-london/ "Johnson Tiles helps poppies bloom at Tower of London"], Johnson Tiles website, 5 November 2014. The poppies were added to the installation progressively by volunteers.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/in-pictures-29935592 "The poppies at the Tower of London"], BBC News, 7 November 2014. The 497,000 kg of the Etruria Marl-based Etruscan red [[earthenware]] used, as well as the majority of the manufacturing equipment and materials, were supplied by Potclays Limited in Stoke-on-Trent.http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Business-Family-firm-Potclays-supplies-materials/story-21090630-detail/story.html][https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/dec/29/tower-poppies-debt-to-the-potteries "Tower poppies’ debt to the Potteries"], ''The Guardian'', 29 December 2014. There were eventually 888,246 of the flowers, representing one count of the number of [[History of the United Kingdom during World War I#Casualties|British and Colonial military fatalities]] in World War I.[http://www.cwgc.org/learning-and-resources/publications/annual-report.aspx Commonwealth War Graves Commission Annual Report 2010–2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151104004037/http://www.cwgc.org/learning-and-resources/publications/annual-report.aspx |date=4 November 2015 }}. This includes a table of numbers of war dead (page 45); 888,246 is the figure for identified burials and names listed on memorials, for the UK and colonies (not including [[dominion]]s). [[File:Poppy Planting (14845374937).jpg|right|thumb|Volunteer planting poppies]] The first poppy was planted on 17 July 2014, and the work was unveiled on 5 August (the centenary of [[History of the United Kingdom during World War I|Britain's entry into the war]]). A team of about 17,500 volunteers put the poppies in place, overseen by Piper and YW Jim Duncan, making this a true public artwork. The last one was planted on 11 November 2014 ([[Remembrance Day]]), by a 13-year-old cadet, Harry Hayes, from the [[Combined Cadet Force|Combined Cadet Force (CCF)]] of [[Reading Blue Coat School]].[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/history/world-war-one/11224043/Cadet-Harry-Hayes-13-plants-last-of-888246-poppies-in-Tower-of-London-moat.html "Cadet Harry Hayes, 13, plants last of 888,246 poppies in Tower of London moat"], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 11 November 2014. After that day a team of about 8,000 volunteers began removing the flowers.[https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-london-30014867 "Tower of London poppies: Volunteers to remove ceramic flowers"], BBC News, 12 November 2014. Members of the public had been able to pre-order the ceramic poppies for £25 each, with a share of the proceeds (estimated at more than £15 million[https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-30100926 "Removal of Tower of London poppies 'at halfway point'"], BBC News, 19 November 2014.) going to six service charities: COBSEO, [[Combat Stress (charitable organisation)|Combat Stress]], [[Coming Home campaign|Coming Home]], [[Help for Heroes]], the [[Royal British Legion]] and [[SSAFA]]. At around sunset each day between 1 September and 10 November, the names of 180 World War I service personnel, nominated by members of the public to appear on a Roll of Honour, were read aloud by a [[Yeomen Warders|Yeoman Warder]] or guest reader, followed by the ''[[Last Post]]'' bugle call.{{cite web|url=http://www.hrp.org.uk/TowerOfLondon/VisitUs/Topthingstoseeanddo/Poppies/RollofHonour|title=Roll of Honour – Submit your nomination|work=Historic Royal Palaces – Tower of London|accessdate=7 November 2014}} ==Official visits and public reaction== [[File:Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red - Roll of Honour at sunset.jpg|left|thumb|Reading of the Roll of Honour, to be followed by playing of the ''Last Post'']] The installation was visited by the Princes [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|William]] and [[Prince Harry|Harry]] and the [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Duchess of Cambridge]] on the day of its opening,[https://web.archive.org/web/20151102062135/http://royalista.com/27639/gallery-kate-william-and-harry-visit-blood-red-sea-of-poppies/ "Kate, William and Harry visit blood red sea of poppies"], royalista.com, 6 August 2014 and by the [[Elizabeth II|Queen]] and [[Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Duke of Edinburgh]] on 16 October.[https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-29642463 "Queen visits Tower of London poppy garden"], BBC News, 16 October 2014.[https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/gallery/2014/oct/16/queen-blood-swept-lands-seas-of-red-in-pictures "Queen visits Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red installation"], ''The Guardian'', 16 October 2014. The Queen later spoke about the memorial in her annual [[Royal Christmas Message|Christmas Message]], broadcast on 25 December 2014. In all, an estimated 5 million people saw the installation,[https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-london-30001177 "Tower of London poppies: Final poppy is 'planted'"], BBC News, 11 November 2014. and the huge visitor demand saw the Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] and other politicians join calls to try and extend the period for which the installation remained at the Tower so that more visitors would be able to pay their respects.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/david-cameron/11214379/David-Cameron-joins-plea-to-extend-Tower-of-London-poppies.html "David Cameron joins plea to extend Tower of London poppies"], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 7 November 2014. Historic Royal Palaces and the artist Paul Cummins resisted such calls, stating that the transience of the installation was a key part of the artistic concept,[https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/nov/06/tower-of-london-poppies-removed-12-november-blood-swept-lands-and-seas-of-red "Tower of London poppies to be removed as planned on 12 November"], ''The Guardian'', 6 November 2014. and that the poppies would be removed as planned and distributed to their purchasers. On 8 November it was announced that ''Wave'', which rose up over the Tower's entrance, would remain in place until the end of the month and that following this, the sculptures ''Wave'' and ''Weeping Window'' would be taken on a tour of the UK, organised by [[14-18 NOW]]. This tour would last until the centenary of the armistice of World War I in November of 2018 and visit 19 locations; after the tour the sculptures would enter the [[Imperial War Museum]]'s collection.[https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-29965477 "Poppy display segment at Tower of London given extension"], BBC News, 8 November 2012.{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-29965477|title= Tower of London poppies: Thousands to go on tour|author= |date= 9 November 2014|website= [[BBC News Online]] |publisher= | accessdate= 7 July 2016 }} A campaign was launched in December 2014 to bring the sculptural elements to Stoke-on-Trent during the tour itinerary as the majority of materials and much of the piece itself were manufactured in the city. In April 2016, about halfway through the tour, ''Weeping Windows'' was installed at [[St Magnus Cathedral]] in [[Kirkwall]], [[Orkney]], Britain's most northerly cathedral, to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the [[Battle of Jutland]], the biggest naval engagement of the First World War.{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Mark|title=Tower of London poppies bloom at Britain's most northerly cathedral|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/22/tower-of-london-poppies-weeping-window-st-magnus-kirkwall-orkney|accessdate=2 July 2016|publisher=The Guardian|date=22 April 2016}} In recognition of the work, Paul Cummins and Tom Piper were both awarded the [[Order of the British Empire|MBE (Member of the Order of the British Empire)]] in the [[2015 New Year Honours]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-30633687 "NY Honours for poppy duo, Joan Collins and John Hurt"], BBC News, 30 December 2014. ==Critical reaction== Although the installation struck a chord with the public, it received negative reactions from some critics in the press. [[A. A. Gill]] of ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' called it "impressive" but "curiously bland".[https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-the-papers-29974714 BBC News paper review], 9 November 2014. ''[[The Guardian]]'s'' art critic [[Jonathan Jones (journalist)|Jonathan Jones]] described it as having a "false nobility" and being a "prettified and toothless" memorial. Tom Piper said in response that "... it is a remarkably good thing that it is so accessible. We should not be trying to create something that is difficult to understand." [[File:My Tower Poppy (16193090801).jpg|thumb|right|upright|Detail showing an individual ceramic poppy]] [[File:Bloodswept Lands and Seas of Red poppies in St John the Baptist's Church, Hillingdon 01.jpg|thumb|Poppies from the display with a certificate in a cabinet at a church]] ==UK tour== In November 2014, it was announced that two sculptures from the installation, ''Wave'' and ''Weeping Window'', would tour venues around the UK until 2018. This was organised by [[14-18 NOW]].[https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-29965477 "Poppy display segment at Tower of London given extension"], BBC News, 8 November 2012.{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-29965477|title= Tower of London poppies: Thousands to go on tour|author= |date= 9 November 2014|website= [[BBC News Online]] |publisher= | accessdate= 7 July 2016 }} The scheduled venues were as follows:{{cite web|title=Locations – 14-18 NOW|url=https://www.1418now.org.uk/commissions/poppies/2017locations/|website=www.1418now.org.uk|publisher=14-18-Now|accessdate=11 July 2017}} ===''Weeping Window''=== {| |- |12 Sep 2015 – 1 Nov 2015||[[Woodhorn (Museum)|Woodhorn Museum]], [[Ashington]], Northumberland |- |7 Nov 2015 – 17 Jan 2016||[[St George's Hall, Liverpool]] |- |22 Apr 2016 – 12 Jun 2016||[[St Magnus Cathedral]], Kirkwall, Orkney |- |30 Jun 2016 – 25 Sep 2016||[[Balhousie Castle|Black Watch Museum]], [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]] |- |12 Oct 2016 – 20 Nov 2016||[[Caernarfon Castle]] |- |25 Mar 2017 – 14 May 2017||[[Hull Maritime Museum]] |- |9 Jun 2017 – 23 Jul 2017||[[Derby Silk Mill|The Silk Mill]], [[Derby]] |- |8 Aug 2017 – 24 Sep 2017||[[Senedd]], [[Cardiff]] |- |14 Oct 2017 – 3 Dec 2017||[[Ulster Museum]], [[Belfast]] |- |14 Mar 2018 – 29 Apr 2018 |[[Hereford Cathedral]] |- |23 May 2018 – 8 Jul 2018 |[[Carlisle Castle]] |- |2 Aug 2018 – 16 Sep 2018 |[[Middleport Pottery]], Stoke-on-Trent |- |5 Oct 2018 – 18 Nov 2018 |[[Imperial War Museum]], London |} ===''Wave''=== {| |- |5 Sep 2015 – 10 Jan 2016||[[Yorkshire Sculpture Park]] |- |28 May 2016 – 4 Sep 2016||[[Lincoln Castle]] |- |12 Apr 2017 – 25 Jun 2017||Barge Pier, [[Shoeburyness]] |- |23 Aug 2017 – 19 Nov 2017 |[[Plymouth Naval Memorial]] |- |13 Apr 2018 – 24 Jun 2018 |[[Royal Armouries at Fort Nelson]] |- |8 Sep 2018 – 25 Nov 2018 |[[Imperial War Museum North]], Manchester |- | |} After the end of the UK-wide 14-18 NOW tour ''Wave'' and ''Weeping Window'' will enter the Imperial War Museum's collection. ==Armistice commemoration== A similar tribute also designed by Piper, ''[[Beyond the Deepening Shadow]]'', in which 10,000 flames were lit, again at the Tower of London, was installed to mark the centenary of the end of the war. It ran nightly, ending on [[Armistice Day]] (11 November) 2018.[https://www.bbc.com/news/av/uk-46086225/tower-of-london-illuminated-for-armistice-tribute "Tower of London illuminated for Armistice tribute"], BBC News, 4 November 2018. ==See also== * [[Remembrance poppy]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://www.1418now.org.uk/ 14-18 NOW Official website] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=58aX_EBwzr4 Video: Making the Poppies (with introduction by Paul Cummins)] * {{Commons category-inline|Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red|''Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red''}} {{Public art in London|state=collapsed}} {{Portal bar|London|Visual arts|World War I}} [[Category:2014 in art]] [[Category:2014 in London]] [[Category:British contemporary works of art]] [[Category:Centenary of the outbreak of World War I]] [[Category:Installation art works]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in London]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in London]] [[Category:Papaver]] [[Category:Tower of London]] [[Category:World War I memorials in the United Kingdom]]

{{Infobox museum |name = Bode Musee |image =Bode_Museum.jpg |imagesize = 300px | map_type = Germany Berlin central#Germany |coordinates = {{coord|52|31|19|N|13|23|41|E|region:DE-BE_type:landmark|display=title,inline}} |established = |location = [[Museum Island]], [[Berlin]] |type = |visitors = |director = |curator = |publictransit = |website = }} [[File:Berlin Monbijoubruecke und Bodemuseum 1904.jpg|thumb|200px|The Bode Museum in 1904]]
The '''Bode Museee''' is one of the group of [[museum]]s on the [[Museum Island]] in [[Berlin]], Germany. It was designed by architect [[Ernst von Ihne]] and completed in 1904. Originally called the '''Kaiser-Friedrich-Museum''' after [[Frederick III, German Emperor|Emperor Frederick III]], the museum was renamed in honour of its first [[curator]], [[Wilhelm von Bode]], in 1956.
==Collections== Closed for repairs since 1997, the museum was reopened on October 18, 2006 after a €156 million refurbishment.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/kultur/berliner-kulturbauten-und-was-sie-kosten-teuer-billig-im-plan/8949466.html |title=Teuer, billig, im Plan: Berliner Kulturbauten und was sie kosten |newspaper=[[Der Tagesspiegel]] |date=17 October 2013 }}</ref> True to the ethos of its founding director, Wilhelm von Bode, who believed in mixing art collections,<ref name="nytimes.com">Alan Riding (November 27, 2006), [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/27/arts/design/27bode.html German Museums Move Closer to Reunification] ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> it is now the home for a collection of [[sculpture]]s, [[Byzantine art]], and [[coin]]s and [[medal]]s.<ref>[http://www.smb.spk-berlin.de/smb/sammlungen/details.php?lang=en&objID=14&p=1 History – Sculpture Collection and Museum of Byzantine Art.]</ref> The presentation of the collections is both geographic and chronological, with the Byzantine and Gothic art of northern and southern Europe displayed separately on the museum’s first floor and a similar regional division of Renaissance and Baroque art on its second floor.<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
The sculpture collection shows art of the [[Eastern Christianity|Christian Orient]] (with an emphasis on [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic]] [[Egypt]]), sculptures from [[Byzantium]] and [[Ravenna]], sculptures of the [[Middle Ages]], the [[art of Italy|Italian]] [[Gothic art|Gothic]], and the early [[Renaissance]]. Late German Gothic works are also represented by [[Tilman Riemenschneider]], the south German Renaissance, and Prussian [[Baroque sculpture|Baroque art]] up to the 18th century. In the future selected works of the [[Gemäldegalerie, Berlin|Gemäldegalerie]] will be integrated into the sculpture collection. This is reminiscent of William von Bode's concept of "style rooms", in which sculptures, paintings, and crafts are viewed together, as was usual in upper middle-class private collections.
The ''Münzkabinett'' ("coin cabinet") is one of the world's largest [[Numismatics|numismatic]] collections. Its range spans from the beginning of [[mint (coin)|minting]] in the 7th century BC in [[Anatolia|Asia Minor]] up to the present day. With approximately 500,000 items the collection is a unique archive for historical research, while its medal collection makes it an important art exhibition at the same time.
Writing in ''[[The Financial Times]]'' on the occasion on the museum's reopening in 2006, [[Neil MacGregor]], director of the [[British Museum]], hailed “the most comprehensive display of European sculpture anywhere.” He added: “It is no exaggeration to say that in the new Bode Museum, Europe will be able for the first time to read its history — aesthetic and religious, intellectual and political — in a three-dimensional form.”<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
==The "Flora" bust== In 1910, it was revealed that a bust of ''[[Flora (mythology)|Flora]]'', which had been purchased by the [[Kaiser Friedrich Museum]], [[Berlin]], under the belief that it was by [[Leonardo da Vinci]], may have actually been created by the English sculptor, [[Richard Cockle Lucas]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Albert Durer Lucas |url=http://www.burlington.co.uk/artist-biography/albert-durer-lucas.html|publisher=Burlington Paintings|accessdate=15 December 2010}}</ref> [[Wilhelm von Bode]], the general manager of the Prussian Art Collections for the Berlin Museum, had spotted the bust in a London gallery and purchased it for a few pounds. Bode was convinced that the bust was by Leonardo and the Berlin Museum authorities, and the German public, were delighted to have "snatched a great art treasure from under the very noses" of the British art world.<ref name="Craddock">{{cite book|last=Craddock|first=Paul |title= Scientific investigation of copies, fakes and forgeries|year=2009|publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann |isbn= 978-0-7506-4205-7 |pages=432–434 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=41g63RVB4fIC&pg=PA432&lpg=PA432&dq=Flora+Bode-Museum&source=bl&ots=wpL7OrLMx_&sig=7kNV80BwYpeuyvrJVsWpXSoKBq0&hl=en&ei=ViEJTfSJJMubhQe74pS9Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CE4Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
Shortly afterwards, ''[[The Times]]'' ran an article claiming that the bust was the work of Lucas, having been commissioned to produce it from a painting. Lucas's son, Albert, then came forward and swore under oath that the story was correct and that he had helped his father to make it. Albert was able to explain how the layers of wax had been built up from old candle ends; he also described how his father would stuff various debris, including newspapers, inside the bust. When the Berlin museum staff removed the base they found the debris, just as Albert had described it, including a letter dated in the 1840s.<ref name="Craddock"/>
Despite this evidence, Bode continued to claim that his original attribution was correct. To support this, he displayed the Flora bust among a selection of Lucas's lesser work – this exhibition rather backfired, however, as it showed that Lucas had been regularly making wax sculptures inspired by the great works of previous times.<ref name="Craddock"/>
Various claims and counter-claims have been put forward about the bust, from its being an outright forgery to being a genuine 16th-century piece (albeit not by Leonardo). Scientific examination has been inconclusive and unhelpful in dating the bust, although it is accepted as having at least some connection with Lucas.<ref name="Craddock"/> The bust remains on display in what is now the Bode Museum [[museum label|labelled "England"]], "19th Century" with a question mark.<ref>{{cite web|last=Härig |first=Beatrice |title=Flora's duel for waxy smile|url=http://www.monumente-online.de/10/01/sonderthema/Madame_Tussaud_Wachsrestaurierung_Moulagen_Wachskunst_Bodemuseum_Flora_Votivfigur.php |publisher="Monumente"|accessdate=15 December 2010|language=German|date=February 2010}}</ref>
==Canadian gold coin theft== On 27 March 2017, a solid gold coin called the [[Big Maple Leaf]], issued by the [[Royal Canadian Mint]] in 2007 as a commemorative piece, was stolen from the museum.<ref name="bbc">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-39409754|title=Solid gold coin worth $4m stolen from Berlin museum|date=2017-03-27|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-03-27|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/mar/28/forging-pound-coins-crime-forgers Guardian report remembers the theft]</ref> The coin, at 53 cm in diameter and 3 cm in thickness, is made of 24-carat gold and is worth around [[Euro|€]]3.7 million.<ref name="telegraph">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/03/27/giant-gold-coin-worth-almost-4-millionstolen-berlin-museum-dawn/|title=Giant gold coin worth almost €4 million stolen from Berlin museum in dawn heist|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2017-03-27|language=en-GB}}</ref> A ladder was found on the train tracks nearby, leading German police to speculate that the thief entered the building by breaking open a window in the back of the museum next to the railway tracks.<ref name=bbc/><ref name=telegraph/>
==Pop culture== The museum appears as a playable level in the World War II video game ''[[Sniper Elite V2]]''.
==See also== * [[List of art museums]] * [[List of museums in Germany]]
