[[GNU Octave]] | m = [...] | det(m) | m.' | m(i,j) | m(:,j) | m(i,:) | eig(m) |- | [[NumPy]] | m = mat(...) | linalg.det(m) | m.T | {{nowrap|m[i-1,j-1]}} | m[:,i-1] | m[i-1,:] | linalg.eigvals(m) |- | [[S-Lang]] | m = reshape([x11, x12, ...], [new-dims]) | | m = transpose(m) | m[i,j] | m[*,j] | m[j,*] | |- | [[SymPy]] | m = Matrix(...) | | m.T | {{nowrap|m[i-1,j-1]}} | | | |- | [[Wolfram Language]] | m = {{x11, x12, ...}, ...} | Det[m] | Transpose[m] | m[[i,j]] | {{nowrap|m[[;;,j]]}} | m[[i]] | Eigenvalues[m] |- |} == References == {{Reflist|refs= The index may be a negative number, indicating the corresponding number of places before the end of the array. Slices for multidimensional arrays are also supported and defined similarly. Slices of the type ''first'':''last'':''step'' are also supported. More generally, for 1-d arrays [[Perl]] and [[S-Lang (programming library)|S-Lang]] allow slices of the form''array''[''indices''], where ''indices'' can be a range such mentioned in footnote 2 or an explicit list of indices, e.g., '[0,9,3,4]', or a mix of both, e.g., A[[[0:3]],7,9,[11:2:-3]]]. ''last'' or ''end'' may be a negative number, indicating to stop at the corresponding number of places before the end of the array. Size can only be chosen on initialization after which it is fixed Allows arrays of arrays which can be used to emulate most—but not all—aspects multi-dimensional arrays Size can only be chosen on initialization when memory is allocated on the heap, as distinguished from when it is allocated on the stack. This note need not be made for a language that always allocates arrays on the heap C99 allows for variable size arrays; however there is almost no compiler available to support this new feature This list is strictly comparing language features. In every language (even assembler) it is possible to provide improved array handling via add on libraries. This language has improved array handling as part of its standard library The class Array is fixed-size, but OrderedCollection is dynamic The indexing base can be 0 or 1 as per the System Variable ⎕IO. This value may apply to the whole "workspace", or be localized to a user-defined function or a single primitive function by use of the Variant operator (⍠) At least 2 dimensions (scalar numbers are 1×1 arrays, vectors are 1×n or n×1 arrays) Allows creating fixed-size arrays in "unsafe" code, allowing enhanced [[interoperability]] with other language Varies by implementation. Newer implementations (FreePascal, Object Pascal (Delphi)) allow heap-based dynamic arrays Behaviour can be tuned via compiler switches. As in DMD 1.0 bounds are checked in debug mode and unchecked in release mode for efficiency Almost all Fortran implementations offer bounds checking options via compiler switches. However by default, bounds checking is usually turned off for efficiency Many implementations (Turbo Pascal, Object Pascal (Delphi), FreePascal) allow the behaviour to be changed by compiler switches and in-line directives COBOL provides a way to specify that the usable size of an array is variable, but this can never be greater than the declared maximum size, which is also the allocated size Most Common Lisp implementations allow checking to be selectively disabled The index type can be a freely chosen [[integer (computer science)|integer type]], [[enumerated type]], or [[character (computing)|character type]]. For arrays with non-compact index types see: [[Associative array]] The default base index is the lowest value of the index type used Standard [[Perl]] array data types do not support vectorized operations as defined here. However, the [[Perl Data Language]] extension adds array objects with this ability The standard [[Python (programming language)|Python]] array type, list, does not support vectorized operations as defined here. However, the [[numpy]] extension adds array objects with this ability By specifying a base index, arrays at an arbitrary base can be created. However, by default, Lua's length operator does not consider the base index of the array when calculating the length. This behavior can be changed via metamethods FreeBASIC supports both variable array lengths and fixed length arrays. Arrays declared with no index range are created as variable-length arrays, while arrays with a declared range are created as fixed-length arrays In these languages, one can access or write to an array index greater than or equal to the length of the array, and the array will implicitly grow to that size. This may appear at first as if the bounds are not checked; however, the bounds are checked in order to decide to grow the array, and you do not have unsafe memory access like you do in C PHP's "arrays" are associative arrays. You can use integers and strings as the keys (indexes); floats can also be used as the key but are truncated to integers. There is not really any "base index" or "bounds" Haskell arrays (Data.Array) allow using any type which is an instance of Ix as index type. So a custom type can be defined and used as an index type as long as it instances Ix. Also, tuples of Ix types are also Ix types; this is commonly used to implement multi-dimensional arrays ALGOL 68 arrays must be subscripted (and sliced) by type INT. However a hash function could be used to convert other types to INT. e.g. name'''['''hash("string")''']''' Because C does not bound-check indices, a pointer to the interior of any array can be defined that will symbolically act as a pseudo-array that accommodates negative indices or any integer index origin COBOL arrays may be indexed with "INDEX" types, distinct from integer types While COBOL only has arrays-of-arrays, array elements can be accessed with a multi-dimensional-array-like syntax, where the language automatically matches the indexes to the arrays enclosing the item being referenced While Golang's Array type is not dynamically sized, the data type [https://tour.golang.org/moretypes/7 Slice] is dynamically-sized and is much more common in use than arrays. The base can be changed when using the System.Array type, but not with T[] (C# syntax). XPath/XQuery has two kinds of arrays. ''Sequences'' (1,2,3) which cannot nest and in the XPath/XQuery 3.1 version ''arrays'' array { 1,2,3 } or [1,2,3] which can. }} [[Category:Arrays|Programming language comparison]] [[Category:Programming language comparisons|*Array]]

{{good article}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Dead Island'' announcement trailer}} {{Infobox advertising | name = Dead Island: Official Announcement Trailer | image = | image_size = | caption = | agency = Axis Animation | client = [[Techland]], [[Deep Silver]] | market = Worldwide | language = English | media = Video | runtime = 187 [[second]]s (3:07) | product = ''[[Dead Island]]'' | released = February 16, 2011 | slogan = | director = Stuart Aitken | music = [[Giles Lamb]] | starring = | production company = Axis Productions | producer = Anton Borkel | country = [[United Kingdom]] | budget = | website = }}
'''''Dead Island: Official Announcement Trailer''''' is an [[advertisement|announcement trailer]] for the 2011 video game ''[[Dead Island]]'', which was developed by [[Techland]] and published by [[Deep Silver]]. The story of the trailer follows a family who is attacked by a horde of zombies in a hotel. The trailer ends with the infected daughter, who has turned into a zombie, being thrown to her death from a hotel window. The trailer was produced by Glasgow-based Axis Animation, with music created by [[Giles Lamb]].
The trailer was designed to be emotional, allowing players to care for the characters and to be distinct from trailers for the game's competitors. The trailer does not show any actual gameplay, instead telling a short story about the game's world and the background behind its events. The development team also had the goal to show the inevitability and the helplessness of a family in a zombie outbreak. Upon its release on February 16, 2011, the trailer sparked public interest, and the community reaction led Techland to adjust the content of the actual game. It was met with a mixed reception from critics. Praise was directed at the trailer's new ideas, story, immersion and tone, however, it received criticism for lacking gameplay information and its depiction of a dead child. The trailer received multiple awards upon release.
==Plot== The story is presented in [[Reverse chronology|reverse chronological order]] and in [[slow motion]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vg247.com/2011/03/23/dead-island-there-is-an-apocalypse-happening/|title=Dead Island: "There is an apocalypse happening"|first=Keza|last=MacDonald|work=[[VG247]]|date=March 23, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/videos/dead-island-cgi-trailer/2300-6299756/|title=Dead Island CGI Trailer|first=Dan|last= Mihoerck |date=February 17, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015|work=[[GameSpot]]}}</ref> The trailer follows a family, consisting of a father, a mother and a daughter, visiting Banoi, an island paradise. After they have settled in a hotel, an unexpected [[zombie outbreak]] occurs.<ref name="Kok"/> The daughter is running away from the horde of zombies in the hotel's corridor and dashing towards her room, where her father and mother are staying, when she is caught. A zombie bites the daughter's legs, causing her to become infected with the zombie virus.
The father opens the door and picks up a [[fire axe]] to fight against zombies. He rescues his daughter and brings her inside the hotel room. After placing the injured daughter on a bed, the couple begin fighting the zombies who are breaking into the room. The zombies overwhelm them, and the daughter turns into a zombie and attacks her father, biting him on the neck. To defend himself, the father struggles, trying to push her off, until he throws her out of the window, breaking the glass. The daughter dies on impact with the ground. While the father is struggling, the mother is attacked and eaten by several zombies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lZqrG1bdGtg|title=Dead Island: Official Announcement Trailer|work=[[IGN]]|date=February 16, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> The corpses of the couple can be seen in a hotel room in the beginning of the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5837416/the-final-moments-of-that-heartbreaking-dead-island-family-discovered-in-the-game|title=The Final Moments of That Heartbreaking Dead Island Family Discovered in the Game|first=Brian|last=Crecente|work=[[Kotaku]]|date=September 6, 2011|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref>
==Development== ''[[Dead Island]]'', originally announced in 2007 by Techland,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/08/08/dead-island-details-rescued|title=Dead Island Details Rescued|first=Daemon|last=Hatfield|work=[[IGN]]|date=August 8, 2007|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> is an [[action role-playing game|action role-playing]] [[survival horror]] video game. Set in a zombie-infested tropical island called Banoi, the game focuses heavily on melee combat. According to Techland, it was a game about killing zombies, not a game focused on delivering an emotional experience.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5775798/that-heartbreaking-dead-island-family-theyre-not-in-the-game|title=That Heartbreaking Dead Island Family? They're Not In The Game|first=Brian|last=Crecente|work=[[Kotaku]]|date=April 3, 2011|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref> Until 2011, Techland declined to give new information regarding the game as requested by the game's publisher, [[Deep Silver]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/coj-dev-still-working-on-dead-island|title=COJ dev still working on Dead Island |first=Ellie|last=Gibson|date=June 7, 2009|accessdate=October 24, 2015|work=[[Eurogamer]]}}</ref> With the lack of new information surrounding the game, many critics believed that the game had been quietly cancelled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/dead-island-trailer-shows-the-worst-vacation-ever/|title=Dead Island Trailer Shows The Worst Vacation Ever|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=February 16, 2011|first=Ryan|last=Fleming|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> The game was released on February 16, 2011, approximately four years after the game's initial announcement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2011/02/16/welcome-to-dead-island|title=Welcome to Dead Island|first=Ryan|last=Geddes|work=[[IGN]]|date=February 16, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref>
The trailer was produced and made by the [[Glasgow]]-based Axis Animation, which had previously created trailers for ''[[Killzone 2]]'' and ''[[Mass Effect 2]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.develop-online.net/news/dead-island-trailer-creators-revealed/0108748|title=Dead Island trailer creators revealed|first=Rob|last=Crossley|work=[[Develop (magazine)|Develop]]|date=February 17, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> According to Stuart Aitken, Axis's Managing Director and Technical Director and the director of the trailer, [[Deep Silver]] gave the team a lot of creative freedom and flexibility in creating the trailer, allowing them to create their own characters instead of using the in-game protagonists.<ref name="Line">{{cite web|url=https://www.list.co.uk/article/37118-dead-island/|title=Dead Island: The game behind the stunning trailer, developed by Axis Animation and Savalas, is finally ready for release|first=Henry|last=Northmore|work=[[The List (magazine)|The List]]|date=August 25, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> Deep Silver had given them a script and general ideas for them to follow, and the team expanded upon it. In order to make the trailer feel [[non-linear]] and focused, the team decided to narrow down the trailer's location to only a single hotel room.<ref name="G4TV">{{cite web|url=http://www.g4tv.com/thefeed/blog/post/710713/dead-island-the-making-of-an-amazing-video-game-trailer/|title=Dead Island: The Making Of An Amazing Video Game Trailer|first=Anthony|last=Hernandez|work=[[G4 (U.S. TV channel)|G4TV]]|date=February 22, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> Deep Silver wanted the trailer to have some exterior environment. As a result, the team added a segment which has the daughter falling from the hotel window; in the process, audiences glimpse the island setting.<ref name="Dev"/>
The team hoped that despite the short duration of the trailer, audiences would understand the story and be connected with its characters. They decided that it would be easy for players to identify with a family and that a story involving parents and children could convey the message quickly.<ref name="G4TV"/> They intended to use the trailer to depict the background information of the game, presenting information regarding the "discovery" of the outbreak, its inevitability,<ref name="Dev">{{cite web|url=http://www.develop-online.net/interview/how-we-made-the-gore-ballet-dead-island-trailer/0116981|title=How we made the 'gore ballet' Dead Island trailer|work=[[Develop (magazine)|Develop]]|first=Rob|last=Crossley|date=February 24, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> and the helplessness of the family. The team had an internal debate on whether the trailer should show guns, ultimately deciding that doing so would distract from the primary goal of the story.<ref name="G4TV"/> The story originally had the mother turn into a zombie, but the team changed it to the daughter, as they considered her more vulnerable when facing a large group of zombies.<ref name="Dev"/> The team was worried that the action and violence featured would seem excessive, and they decided to alleviate the problem by introducing non-chronological storytelling.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/109577-Dead-Island-Publisher-Shares-Its-Trailer-Making-Secrets|title=Dead Island Publisher Shares Its Trailer-Making Secrets|first=Logan|last=Westbrook|work=[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]|date=April 29, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> Deep Silver also proposed to mitigate the violence by having the trailer presented in [[slow motion]], as they believed that it could make the action feel "balletic" instead of purely violent.<ref name="Dev"/>
The trailer is made up of [[computer imagery]], and it does not show any actual gameplay footage of ''Dead Island''.<ref name="Line"/> The team hoped to use the trailer as a piece of "artwork", stating influence from the ''Carousel'' trailer from [[Philips]].<ref name="Escapist">{{cite web|url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/articles/view/video-games/issues/issue_303/8817-The-Ballet-of-Death|first=Robert|last=Rath|title=Rise From Your Grave: The Ballet Of Death|work=[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]|date=April 26, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> The trailer was also designed to showcase "great zombie moments" in an effort to attract the genre's supporters.<ref name="Dev"/> The actual game development team used the trailer to build up the mood and atmosphere for the game, and they designed quests which required players to help people who had lost their families. They hoped that the mood would make players feel that they were the only hope existing on the island.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2011/07/paradise-lost-how-dead-island-hopes-to-live-up-to-emotional-trailer/|title=How Dead Island hopes to live up to emotional trailer|first=Andrew|last=Webster|work=[[Ars Technica]]|date=July 15, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref>
The trailer's music was composed by [[Giles Lamb]], who worked for a soundtrack development company called Savalas.<ref name="Line"/> The music was designed to be "somber", "melancholy", and "elegant",<ref name="Dev"/> in contrast with the gore presented in the trailer.<ref name="Line"/> The music was designed to be tense when the trailer is depicting violent action, and beautiful during peaceful moments. The team hoped that the music would create a "juxtaposition between beauty and horror".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2011/02/25/dead-island-cinematic-designer-responds-to-mixed-trailer-reactions.aspx|title=Dead Island Cinematic Designer Responds To Mixed Trailer Reactions|first=Annette|last=Gonzalez|date=February 25, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015|work=[[Game Informer]]}}</ref>
Popular reaction to the trailer led Techland to slightly adjust the game's tone, gameplay, and story, as well as the game's promotion strategy.<ref name="Poly">{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2012/11/14/3537988/dead-island-the-reckoning|title=Dead Island: The Reckoning|first=Russ|last=Pitts|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=February 21, 2012|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref><ref name="views">{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2011/09/02/dead-island-release-trailer/|title=How a viral trailer set up Dead Island as a triple-A game release next week|first=Matthew|last=Lynley|work=[[VentureBeat]]|date=September 2, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref>
==Reception== A week after the release of the trailer, more than one million people had viewed it through [[YouTube]], exceeding Deep Silver's expectation of only 100,000 views.<ref name="views"/> ''Dead Island'' also became one of the most searched items on [[Google]], [[YouTube]], and [[Twitter]] for several days.<ref name="views"/> Axis was pleasantly surprised at the trailer's popularity.<ref name="Dev"/> Following the trailer's release, ''Dead Island'' became a widely anticipated game.<ref name="views"/>
Many critics praised the trailer's use of reverse storytelling. Keith Stuart from ''[[The Guardian]]'' compared it favorably to [[Coldplay]]'s "[[The Scientist (song)|The Scientist]]", saying that it successfully delivered an affecting and emotive experience.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/gamesblog/2011/feb/17/dead-island-trailer-controversial|title=Dead Island: Will It Be The Most Controversial Trailer Ever Made|first=Keith|last=Sturat|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=February 17, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> Mike Fahey from ''[[Kotaku]]'' called the trailer's use of the dead girl "heartbreaking" and thought that it would be amazing if Techland was able to incorporate these emotional elements into the actual game.<ref name="Kok">{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5762287/dead-island-returns-and-a-little-girl-dies|title=The Most Heartbreaking Zombie Video Game Trailer You'll Ever See|first=Mike|last=Fahey|work=[[Kotaku]]|date=February 16, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> Its graphics and pacing also received commendation.<ref name="Reception">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-problem-with-game-trailers/1100-6365663/|title=The Problem With Game Trailers|first=Laura|last= Parker |date=March 12, 2012|accessdate=October 24, 2015|work=[[GameSpot]]}}</ref> The trailer's story was praised for presenting an unconventional take on a zombie apocalypse.<ref name="reception">{{cite web|url=http://www.kotaku.com.au/2011/09/dead-islands-trailer-was-amazing-appalling-and-enlightening/|title=Dead Island's Trailer Was Amazing, Appalling And Enlightening|first=Kirk|last=Hamilton|work=[[Kotaku]]|date=September 13, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> Jason Schreier from ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' said that the trailer had successfully made a saturated genre feel fresh again.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2011/02/dead-island-trailer/|title=Don't Get Caught Up In Dead Island Trailer Hype|first=Jason|last=Schreier|work=[[Wired.co.uk]]|date=February 17, 2011|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref>
The trailer generated controversy around the depiction of the daughter's death. Fahey said that such elements are something video games usually "shy away from", yet it is presented as a main focus in the trailer.<ref name="Kok"/> Ben Parfitt from ''[[Market for Home Computing and Video Games]]'' found it offensive and thought that the team had stepped across the mark.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcvuk.com/news/read/opinion-that-dead-island-trailer/04843|title=OPINION: That Dead Island trailer|first=Ben|last=Parfitt|work=[[Market for Home Computing and Video Games]]|date=February 17, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> Defending the trailer, Axis said that their depiction fit the overarching narrative.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/dead-island-trailer-creator-speaks-to-dead-girl-controversy/|title=Dead Island trailer creator speaks to dead girl controversy|first=Matt|last=Bradford|work=[[GamesRadar]]|date=February 24, 2011|accessdate=October 24, 2015}}</ref> Robert Rath from ''[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]'' also liked the segment, calling it "deliberate and necessary", and thought that the overall effect would have been significantly hampered if had been removed from the trailer.<ref name="Escapist"/>
The lack of gameplay information was also criticized. Laura Parker found the trailer disconnected from the actual game, with the trailer being misleading by not showing any in-game information, and with the game failing to deliver the same emotional effect as the trailer.<ref name="Reception"/> Daemon Hatfield from [[IGN]] similarly thought that the trailer was not useful in assessing the game's quality and expressed concerns that the game would not be as entertaining and interesting as the trailer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2011/03/04/gdc-is-dead-island-anything-like-its-debut-trailer|title=GDC: Is Dead Island Anything Like Its Debut Trailer|first=Daemon|last=Hatfield|work=[[IGN]]|date=March 3, 2011|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref> Upon release, many reviewers thought that the trailer had set expectation too high for the actual game, and that the game ended up not meeting expectations.<ref name="reception"/>
The trailer was given a gold award at the [[Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2011/06/29/dead-island-trailer-wins-gold-award-at-cannes-advertising-fe/|title=Dead Island trailer wins Gold award at Cannes ... advertising festival|first=Christopher|last=Grant|work=[[Joystiq]]|date=June 29, 2011|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref> It was named by gaming journalists as one of the best video game trailers ever made.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.videogamer.com/features/article/ten_of_the_best_cgi_game_trailers.html|title=Ten of the Best CGI Game Trailers|work=VideoGamer.com|date=February 17, 2011|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/the-best-game-trailers-of-the-generation-1462534128|title=The Best Game Trailers Of The Generation|first=Kirk|last=Hamilton|work=[[Kotaku]]|date=November 11, 2013|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/12/11/the-14-best-game-trailers-of-2014|title=The 14 Best Game Trailers Of 2014|first=Marty|last=Silva|work=[[IGN]]|date=December 11, 2014|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref>
===Legacy=== A live-action remake and a recut version of the trailer which shows the story in a chronological order were released by fans.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/11/3/5061620/dead-island-trailer-live-action-remake|title=Watch the gloriously gory 'Dead Island' trailer re-enacted in live action|first=Vlad|last=Savov |date=November 3, 2013|accessdate=October 25, 2015|work=[[The Verge]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2011/02/17/dead-island-trailer-re-cut-in-chronological-order.aspx|title=Dead Island Trailer Re-Cut In Chronological Order|first=Matt|last=Helgeson|date=February 17, 2011|accessdate=October 25, 2015|work=[[Game Informer]]}}</ref> The announcement trailer also boosted the popularity of Techland and Deep Silver.<ref name="Poly"/> The announcement trailer for ''[[Dead Island: Riptide]]'', released in 2012, featured a similar, depressing tone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/dead_island_riptide/b/xbox360/archive/2012/09/18/another-gorgeous-depressing-cg-trailer.aspx|title=Dead Island Riptide: Another Gorgeous, Depressing CG Trailer|first=Tim|last=Turi|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=September 18, 2012|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref> A trailer for ''[[Goat Simulator]]'' in 2014 also mimicked the format of the ''Dead Island'' announcement trailer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/goat-simulator-pulls-a-dead-island-for-its-emotional-launch-trailer-272493.phtml|title=Goat Simulator pulls a Dead Island for its emotional launch trailer|first=Jordan|last=Devore|work=[[Destructoid]]|date=March 26, 2014|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref> A movie tie-in based on the trailer was once proposed by [[Lionsgate]], though the project was ultimately cancelled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/8/1/5960827/dead-island-movie-deep-silver|title=Hollywood taking a second stab at a Dead Island movie|first=Michael|last=McWhertor|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=August 1, 2014|accessdate=October 25, 2015}}</ref> Deep Silver released a musical tribute to the trailer, coinciding with the launch of ''[[Dead Island: Definitive Edition]]'' in May 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/heres-a-musical-tribute-to-the-dead-island-trailer-in-case-you-wanted-to-cry-today/?|title=Here's a musical tribute to the Dead Island trailer, in case you wanted to cry today|first=Sam|last=Prett|work=[[GamesRadar]]|date=May 31, 2016|accessdate=May 31, 2016}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{infobox book | | name = Empress Bianca | title_orig = | translator = | image = | caption = | author = [[Lady Colin Campbell]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = Novel | publisher = Arcadia Books Ltd (2005)
Dynasty Press (2008) | release_date = 2005/ 2008 | english_release_date = | media_type = | pages = 435 (2005) | isbn = 978-1-900850-90-2 |isbn_note= (2005)
0955350700 (2008) | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Empress Bianca''''', the first novel by [[Lady Colin Campbell]], was initially published in June 2005. One month later, Arcadia Books, the British publisher, withdrew the book and pulped all unsold copies in reaction to a legal threat initiated on behalf of [[Lily Safra]] under her interpretation that the book was a defamatory [[roman à clef]]. After some changes the book was republished in the United States in 2008 by Dynasty Press. ==Plot== Bianca Barrett, the protagonist and daughter of a Welsh Surveyor and his Palestinian wife, becomes an "ambitious and mercenary" social climber and double murderess. Charming and well-educated, Bianca marries four times and advances in wealth and social influence. With Bernardo, her first husband, Bianca has three children; they lose their son in a car crash. After a divorce, she marries the rich Fredie whose family owns the Piedraplata commercial empire. Before it comes to a divorce, the second husband is shot and killed by a hitman who makes it look like a suicide. The killing is arranged by her lover, Phillipe Mahfud, and Bianca becomes the financial beneficiary. After a brief marriage to husband number three – she had married him only to make Mahfud jealous-, she lastly marries Mahfud, a rich Iraqi businessman and banker. When their relationship sours, the banker dies with his nurse in a mysterious fire in his apartment in the tax haven of [[Andorra]]. Bianca's lawyers pay off the police and investigators, and the only justice that remains is in the court of public opinion. ==Pulping of first edition== In July 2005, Lily Safra claimed that her life had been "stolen" by the book and had her lawyer, [[Anthony Julius]], demand that the publisher should recall the book and destroy unsold copies.{{cite web|last1=Barnes|first1=Anthony|last2=Pyke|first2=Nicholas |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/news/pulp-fiction-the-millionaire-socialite-the-english-lady-and-a-book-too-far-500003.html|title= Pulp fiction: the millionaire socialite, the English Lady and a book too far. |publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=24 July 2005|accessdate=12 April 2011}} Julius' letter indicated that Safra "regarded the book as defamatory".{{cite book| author=[[Isabel Vincent]] |title=Golden Lily |publisher=HarperCollinsPublishers, 2010| pages=267f |ISBN=978-0-06-113393-0}} As [[English defamation law]] puts the burden of proof on the defendant, Arcadia Books complied indicating that they were too small a company to fight the looming legal battle. The author, however, denied that she had used Safra's life as a template and claimed that it was based on characters of her own family, including her cousin Blanche, a double murderess.{{cite web| url=http://business.scotsman.com/interviews/Interview-Lady-Colin-Campbell-.5640892.jp |author=Catherine Deveney |title=Interview: Lady Colin Campbell – All about my mother. |publisher=Scotsman.com|date=13 September 2009 |accessdate=12 April 2011 }} A countersuit ensued with Lady Campbell demanding compensation for lost income. She did not prevail.[http://www.5rb.com/docs/Campbell-v-Safra%20QBD%2012%20Apr%202006.pdf Court proceedings Campbell vs Safra, December 4, 2006] A rewritten, American edition of the novel was published in 2008 after the 17 specific issues that had been seen as pointing to Safra were addressed. With changes described as minor, but legally important{{cite web|url=http://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/arts/content/arts/2008/12/19/CampbellKohl1220.html |author=Robert Janjigian |title=Jana Kohl, Lady Colin Campbell talk at Palm Beach author breakfast. |publisher=Palm Beach Daily News |date=19 December 2008 |accessdate=12 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309065017/http://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/arts/content/arts/2008/12/19/CampbellKohl1220.html |archivedate=9 March 2012 |df=dmy }} – for instance, Barret now grows up in [[Mexico]] (not [[South America]]), her mother is Palestinian (not Jewish), and her last husband Iraqi (not Lebanese) – this edition still preserved story, plot, incidents, and dialogue elements.{{cite web |url=http://www.dynastypress.co.uk/article3.html |title=Press release by Dynasty Press on the publication of Empress Bianca. US launch September 2008 in response to law suit from Brazilian born billionaire widow Lily Safra |date=September 2008 |accessdate=12 April 2011 |author=Dynasty Press }} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} [[Category:2005 British novels]] [[Category:Adultery in novels]] [[Category:British crime novels]] [[Category:Debut novels]] [[Category:English defamation law]] [[Category:English novels]] [[Category:Novels set in Andorra]] [[Category:Recalled publications]]

:''This article is about executive agreements between nations in general. For information on executive agreements in US foreign policy, see [[Foreign policy of the United States]].''
An '''executive agreement'''<ref>{{cite book|last1=Green|first1=William|editor1-last=Schultz|editor1-first=David|editor2-last=Vile|editor2-first=John R.|title=The Encyclopedia of Civil Liberties in America|date=2004|publisher=Routledge|location=Armonk, NY|isbn=9781317457138|pages=345–348|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KngGCAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA359&dq=encyclopedia%20of%20civil%20liberties%20in%20america%20%22william%20crawford%20green%22&pg=PA345#v=onepage&q=encyclopedia%20of%20civil%20liberties%20in%20america%20%22william%20crawford%20green%22&f=false|accessdate=25 April 2016|ref=EncycCivLib|language=en}}</ref> is an agreement between the [[head of government|heads of government]] of two or more nations that has not been ratified by the [[legislature]] as [[treaty|treaties]] are ratified. Executive agreements are considered ''politically binding'' to distinguish them from [[treaty|treaties]] which are ''legally binding''.
In the [[United States]], executive agreements are made solely by the [[President of the United States]]. They are one of three mechanisms by which the United States enters into binding international obligations. Some authors consider executive agreements to be [[treaty|treaties]] under [[international law]] in that they bind both the United States and another [[sovereign state]]. However, under United States constitutional law, executive agreements are not considered treaties for the purpose of the [[Treaty Clause]] of the [[United States Constitution]], which requires the advice and consent of two-thirds of the [[United States Senate|Senate]] to qualify as a treaty.
Some other nations have similar provisions with regard to the ratification of treaties.
==In general== Executive agreements are often used in order to bypass the requirements of national [[constitution]]s for ratification of [[treaty|treaties]]. Many nations that are [[republic]]s with written constitutions have constitutional rules about the ratification of treaties. The [[Organization for Security and Co-Operation in Europe]] is based on executive agreements.
==In the United States== In the United States, executive agreements are binding internationally if they are negotiated and entered into under the president's authority in foreign policy, as commander-in-chief of the armed forces, or from a prior act of Congress. For instance, as commander-in-chief the President negotiates and enters into [[status of forces agreement]]s (SOFAs), which govern the treatment and disposition of U.S. forces stationed in other nations. The president cannot, however, enter unilaterally into executive agreements on matters that are beyond his constitutional authority. In such instances, an agreement would need to be in the form of a [[congressional-executive agreement]], or a [[treaty]] with Senate advice and consent.
The [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]], in ''[[United States v. Pink]]'' (1942), held that international executive agreements validly made have the same legal status as treaties and did not require Senate approval. Also, in ''[[Reid v. Covert]]'' (1957), while reaffirming the president’s ability to enter into executive agreements, the Court held that such agreements cannot contradict existing [[United States Code|federal law]] or the Constitution.
The [[Case Act of 1972]] requires the president to inform the Senate within 60 days of any executive agreement being made. No restriction was placed on presidential powers to make such agreements. The notification requirement enabled Congress to vote to cancel an executive agreement, or to refuse to fund its implementation.<ref>[http://wps.prenhall.com/wps/media/objects/434/445252/DocumentsLibrary/docs/caseact.htm Case Act on Executive Agreements (1972)]</ref>
==See also== * [[Congressional-executive agreement]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:International law]] [[Category:Diplomatic documents]]

revision.text:
{{Nofootnotes|date=February 2008}}
'''Family cookbooks''' are collections of recipes, sometimes including family history and photos of the family members. These cookbooks may be written in notebooks, put in ring binders, or professionally published by one of several cookbook publishers that cater to families interested in preserving their food heritage.
Families interested in [[genealogy]] sometimes also decide to preserve their recipes, since those recipes often represent a facet of their history. Some older recipes may give clues as to the ethnic origins of the people who cooked it, like [[lebkuchen]] with its German origins or sweet potato pie and its [[southern United States]] roots. Other genealogical clues may be found in recipe boxes, from the things the recipes are written on: old bills (may indicate where a family lived), letters (may contain stories about what was happening in their lives at the time), or newspaper clippings (may have dates).
Other than the historical/genealogical aspect of a family cookbook, they also serve as a way to pass along [[family traditions]] to another generation. It is worth the time to measure the ingredients of a cook who makes her/his dishes from memory, as they prepare it. Some recipes may become lost when the person who always made that recipe (from memory) dies if it's not written down. In addition to the recipe itself, stories about the tradition are also good to include, perhaps special [[Christmas cookies]] were set out for [[Santa Claus]] for many generations, or a traditional Irish meal was made every [[St. Patrick's Day]].
For large families who need to print 100 or more copies of their cookbook, there are several publishers who specialize in printing limited numbers of books. Smaller families have the option of going to their local printer (such as [[Kinko's]]), or doing it at home with [[desktop publishing]].
==See also== *[[Commonplace book]] *[[Family traditions]]
==Further reading== *Banker, Susan M. ''Scrapbooking with Recipes''. Meredith Publishing Group: Des Moines, IA. 2003. *Rehmel, Judy. ''So, You Want to Write a Cookbook!''. Marathon International Publishing Company: Louisville, KY. 1984. ''out-of-print'' *Steligo, Kathy. ''Meals and Memories: How to Create Keepsake Cookbooks''. Carlo Press: San Carlos, CA. 1999.
[[Category:Cookbooks]] [[Category:Family]]

{{Multiple issues|{{peacock|date=February 2018}}{{essay-like|date=February 2018}}}}
{{Infobox organization | name = The Fellowship of American Bibliophilic Societies | native_name = | native_name_lang = | named_after = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = FABS | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = <!-- use {{start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | founder = eight American book clubs | founding_location = | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = Association (book collecting clubs) | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = Coordinate activities & publications among member clubs | headquarters = | location = | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline, title}} --> | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = Chair | leader_name = Michael Thompson, The Caxton Club<ref>{{cite web|title=FABS Societies Officers|url=http://www.fabsocieties.org/officers.html|access-date=November 13, 2017}}</ref> | leader_title2 = Vice-Chair | leader_name2 = Joan Knoertzer, The Miniature Book Society | leader_title3 = Treasurer | leader_name3 = Philip Anderson, The Rowfant Club | leader_title4 = Secretary | leader_name4 = Ronald K. Smeltzer, The Grolier Club | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | endowment_year = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|http://www.fabsocieties.org}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }}
'''The Fellowship of American Bibliophilic Societies''' (FABS) is an association of American book clubs whose members seek interaction with book collectors across the country and around the world. At The Rowfant Club's 100th anniversary celebration in 1992, local members and their guests from book clubs in New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, and San Francisco discovered common interests of [[bibliophilic]] book clubs.<ref>{{cite web|title=About FABS|url=http://www.fabsocieties.org/about.html|access-date=November 12, 2017}}</ref> The new association's first meeting was November 5, 1993, in New York, at [[Grolier Club|The Grolier Club]]. In 1994, the group drew up articles of association outlining their goals to promote and develop common interests of the member societies.<ref>{{cite web|title=F.A.B.S. Newsletter, Volume 1, Number 1, Winter 1995|url=http://www.fabsocieties.org/newsletters/1.1.pdf|access-date=November 12, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Book Talk: Essays on Books, Booksellers, Collecting, and Special Collections: Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5j5rKevsB5IC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=introduction&f=false|access-date=November 12, 2017}}</ref>
Founding member book clubs were (in chronologic order of the year of the club's founding): The Grolier Club of New York City (1884); [[The Club of Odd Volumes]], Boston (1886); The Rowfant Club, Cleveland (1892); The Philobiblon Club, Philadelphia (1893); [[Caxton Club|The Caxton Club]], Chicago (1895); [[Book Club of California|The Book Club of California]] (1912); [[Roxburghe Club|The Roxburghe Club]], San Francisco (1927); and The Baxter Society, Portland, Maine (1984).
== Select Member Clubs ==
Member clubs include The Aldus Society, Columbus, Ohio<ref>{{cite web|title=The Aldus Society|url=http://aldussociety.com/|access-date=November 12, 2017}}</ref>; The Ampersand Club, Minneapolis, Minnesota<ref>{{cite web|title=The Ampersand Club|url=http://www.theampersandclub.org/|access-date=November 12, 2017}}</ref>; The Baltimore Bibliophiles, Baltimore, Maryland<ref>{{cite web|title=The Baltimore Bibliophiles|url=http://www.baltimorebibliophiles.org/|access-date=November 12, 2017}}</ref>; The Baxter Society; The Book Club of California, San Francisco, California; The Caxton Club, Chicago, Illinois; [[The Book Club of Detroit]], Detroit, Michigan; The Grolier Club, New York, New York <ref>{{cite web|title=The Grolier Club|url=http://www.grolierclub.org/|access-date=November 12, 2017}}</ref>; [[Manuscript Society|The Manuscript Society]]; [[Movable Book Society]]; The Northern Ohio Bibliophilic Society, Cleveland, Ohio<ref>{{cite web|title=Northern Ohio Bibliophilic Society|url=http://nobs.nobsweb.org/|access-date=November 12, 2017}}</ref>; The Philobiblon Club, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; The Rowfant Club, Cleveland, Ohio; The Roxburghe Club of San Francisco; The Ticknor Society, Boston, Massachusetts<ref>{{cite web|title=The Ticknor Society|url=https://www.ticknor.org/|access-date=November 12, 2017}}</ref>; The Book Club of Washington, Seattle, Washington<ref>{{cite web|title=Book Club of Washington|url=http://bookclubofwashington.org/|access-date=November 27, 2018}}</ref>; and The Zamorano Club, Los Angeles, California <ref>{{cite web|title=The Zamorano Club|url=http://www.zamoranoclubla.org|access-date=November 12, 2017}}</ref>.
== Select International Affiliates ==
International affiliates include Aberystwyth Bibliographical Group, Aberystwyth, Wales<ref>{{cite web|title=Aberystwyth Bibliographical Group|url=http://users.aber.ac.uk/das/texts/aberbibgr1.htm|access-date=November 12, 2017}}</ref>; {{ill|Nederlands Genootschap van Bibliofielen|nl}}, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Associació de Bibliòfiles de Barcelona, Barcelona, Spain; [[National Union of Bibliophiles]], Moscow, Russia; The Society of Bibliophiles in Capetown, Capetown, South Africa; Les Amis Du Livre Contemporain, Paris, France<ref>{{cite web|title=Les Amis du Livre Contemporain|url=http://www.les-amis-du-livre-contemporain.fr/|access-date=November 15, 2017}}</ref>; [[Private Libraries Association|The Private Libraries Association]], Pinner, Middlesex, Endland; {{ill|Pirckheimer-Gesellschaft|de}}, Berlin, Germany.
== Activities ==
The National Collegiate Book Collecting Contest, founded in 2005 by Fine Books & Collections Magazine, was led starting in 2010 by a partnership of the [[Antiquarian Booksellers' Association of America]] (ABAA), the Fellowship of American Bibliophilic Societies (FABS), the Grolier Club, and the [[Center for the Book]] and the Rare Books and Special Collections Division of the [[Library of Congress]],<ref>{{cite web|title=The National Collegiate Book Collecting Contest |url=https://www.loc.gov/item/prn-10-033/library-to-co-sponsor-collegiate-book-collecting-contest/2010-02-22/ |access-date=March 13, 2018}}</ref> with support by the Jay I. Kislak Foundation.
The contest encourages young book collectors. Similar contests have been held at colleges and universities across the United States, such as the [[Swarthmore College]] [[A. Edward Newton|A. E. Newton]] Award Book Collecting Contest dating from the 1930s.<ref>{{cite web|title=A. E. Newton Book Collecting Contest|url=http://bookaward.swarthmore.edu/|access-date=November 15, 2017}}</ref> Students from all schools, regardless of whether their school has a similar contest, and regardless of whether they've won similar contests, are encouraged to participate. The awards ceremony is held at the Library of Congress.
==See also== * [[Book collecting]] * [[Books in the United States]] * [[Miniature book]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * http://www.fabsocieties.org/ * http://fabsclubnews.blogspot.com/ * http://fabsbooks.org/

revision.text:
The '''Graph500''' is a rating of supercomputer systems, focused on [[Data-intensive computing|data-intensive loads]]. The project was announced on [[International Supercomputing Conference]] in June 2010. The first list was published at the [[Supercomputing Conference|ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference]] in November 2010. New versions of the list are published twice a year. The main performance metric used to rank the supercomputers is [[Traversed edges per second|GTEPS]] ([[giga]]- [[traversed edges per second]]).
Richard Murphy from Sandia, says that "The Graph500's goal is to promote awareness of complex data problems", instead of focusing on computer benchmarks like HPL (High Performance Linpack), which [[TOP500]] is based on.<ref name="inside-exascale-2012-03">{{cite web|url=http://insidehpc.com/2012/03/15/the-case-for-the-graph-500-really-fast-or-really-productive-pick-one/|title=The Case for the Graph 500 – Really Fast or Really Productive? Pick One|author=The Exascale Report|publisher=Inside HPC|date=2012-03-15}}</ref>
Despite its name, there were several hundreds of systems in the rating, growing up to 174 in June 2014.<ref name="graph500.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.graph500.org/results_jun_2014 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140628045351/http://www.graph500.org/results_jun_2014 |archivedate=2014-06-28 |df= }}</ref>
The algorithm and implementation that won the championship is published in the paper titled "Extreme scale breadth-first search on supercomputers".<ref>http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/7840705/</ref>
There is also list Green Graph 500, which uses same performance metric, but sorts list according to performance per Watt, like [[Green 500]] works with [[TOP500]] (HPL).
== Benchmark == The benchmark used in Graph500 stresses the communication subsystem of the system, instead of counting double precision floating-point.<ref name="inside-exascale-2012-03"/> It is based on a breadth-first search in a large undirected graph (a model of [[Kronecker graph]] with average degree of 16). There are two computation kernels in the benchmark: the first kernel is to generate the graph and compress it into sparse structures CSR or CSC (Compressed Sparse Row/Column); the second kernel does a parallel BFS search of some random vertices (64 search iterations per run). Six possible sizes (Scales) of graph are defined: toy (2<sup>26</sup> vertices; 17 GB of RAM), mini (2<sup>29</sup>; 137 GB), small (2<sup>32</sup>; 1.1 TB), medium (2<sup>36</sup>; 17.6 TB), large (2<sup>39</sup>; 140 TB), and huge (2<sup>42</sup>; 1.1 PB of RAM).<ref>[https://sites.google.com/site/tokyotechsuzumuralab/publication/Graph500-IISWC2011-camera-ready.pdf?attredirects=0 Performance Evaluation of Graph500 on Large-Scale Distributed Environment] // IEEE IISWC 2011, Austin, TX; [https://sites.google.com/site/tokyotechsuzumuralab/publication/Graph500-201111.pdf?attredirects=0 presentation]</ref>
The reference implementation of the benchmark contains several versions:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osp.ru/os/2011/01/13006961/|title= Graph500: адекватный рейтинг| publisher=Open Systems #1 2011|language=ru}}</ref> * serial high-level in [[GNU Octave]] * serial low-level in C * parallel C version with usage of [[OpenMP]] * two versions for [[Cray XMT|Cray-XMT]] * basic [[Message Passing Interface|MPI]] version (with MPI-1 functions) * optimized MPI version (with [[Message Passing Interface|MPI-2]] one-sided communications) The implementation strategy that have won the championship on the Japanese K computer is described in.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ueno|first=K.|last2=Suzumura|first2=T.|last3=Maruyama|first3=N.|last4=Fujisawa|first4=K.|last5=Matsuoka|first5=S.|date=2016-12-01|title=Extreme scale breadth-first search on supercomputers|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/7840705/|journal=2016 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data)|pages=1040–1047|doi=10.1109/BigData.2016.7840705}}</ref>
== Top 10 ranking == === 2016 === According to June 2016 release of the list:<ref>http://www.graph500.org/results_jun_2016</ref>

revision.text: {{Use British English|date=February 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = hibu | logo = Hibu logo.svg | type = [[Privately owned company]] | foundation = 2001 | location = [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]], Berkshire, United Kingdom | key_people = Alfred Mockett (Chairman), David Sharman (Group CEO), Richard Hanscott (CEO UK), Kevin Jasper (CEO US) http://hibucorporate.com/leadership-team | industry = Media | products = | num_employees = 12,531 (2012)[http://2012annualreport.yellgroup.com/overview/our-markets-and-channels Yell Group Plc Annual Report 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131008213949/http://2012annualreport.yellgroup.com/overview/our-markets-and-channels |date=8 October 2013 }} | parent = | subsid = [[Yell (company)| Yell]] | homepage = [http://hibucorporate.com/ hibucorporate.com] | footnotes = }} '''Hibu''' (styled '''hibü'''), formerly '''Yell Group plc''', is a [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] directories and internet services company headquartered in [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]], [[Berkshire]], UK. It has operations in the United Kingdom (known as Yell), the United States, and Spain (known as Paginas Amarillas). It has its origins in the [[yellow pages]] division of the [[privatization|privatised]] British telecommunications operator [[BT Group]]. ==History== ===1966–2001=== In 1966, [[Post Office Telecommunications]] – a division of the UK [[Post Office (United Kingdom)|General Post Office]], launched the first UK Yellow Pages classified directory in [[Brighton]], Sussex.{{cite web|url=http://www.yellgroup.com/english/aboutyell-yelluk-yellukhistory-19601969|title=Yell History – 1960–1969|publisher=Yell.com|accessdate=11 January 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118235429/http://www.yellgroup.com/english/aboutyell-yelluk-yellukhistory-19601969|archivedate=18 January 2008|df=dmy-all}} Yellow Pages were rolled out across the UK by 1973,{{cite web|url=http://www.yellgroup.com/english/aboutyell-yelluk-yellukhistory-19701979|title=Yell History – 1970–1979|publisher=Yell.com|accessdate=11 January 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208134328/http://www.yellgroup.com/english/aboutyell-yelluk-yellukhistory-19701979|archivedate=8 February 2008|df=dmy-all}} and became the first information provider on [[Prestel]]. Yellow Pages launched its iconic ''[[J. R. Hartley]]'' [[advertising|adverts]] in 1983, and became a separately identified business within the BT Group after BT was privatised in 1984. The red fronted ''Business Pages'' launched in 1985 in [[Bristol]] and [[South Wales]], and the telephone directory enquiries information service ''Talking Pages'' was piloted in [[Brighton]] and [[Bristol]] from 1987,{{cite web|url=http://www.yellgroup.com/english/aboutyell-yelluk-yellukhistory-19801989|title=Yell History – 1980–1989|publisher=Yell.com|accessdate=11 January 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208134333/http://www.yellgroup.com/english/aboutyell-yelluk-yellukhistory-19801989|archivedate=8 February 2008|df=dmy-all}} which then became known as 118 24 7 after 2003.[http://www.yell.com/118247/ 118 24 7] website The group launched [[Yellow pages|Yell.com]], its UK local search engine, in 1996{{cite web|url=http://www.yellgroup.com/english/aboutyell-yelluk-yellukhistory-19901999|title=Yell History – 1990–1999|publisher=Yell.com|accessdate=11 January 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208134338/http://www.yellgroup.com/english/aboutyell-yelluk-yellukhistory-19901999|archivedate=8 February 2008|df=dmy-all}} and acquired YellowBook USA in 1999 for $665 million.[http://www.yellgroup.com/english/media-pressreleases-1999-btbuysyellowbookusa BT Buys Yellow Book USA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061111165230/http://www.yellgroup.com/english/media-pressreleases-1999-btbuysyellowbookusa |date=11 November 2006 }} Press Release, 26 August 1999 The Group was renamed Yell in 2000[http://www.yellgroup.com/english/media-pressreleases-2000-yellowpagestobecomeyellplc Yellow Pages to become Yell plc] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720150103/http://www.yellgroup.com/english/media-pressreleases-2000-yellowpagestobecomeyellplc |date=20 July 2011 }} Press Release, 13 April 2000 and BT restructured in 2001 and agreed to sell the Yell directory business to private equity firms [[Apax Partners]] and [[HM Capital Partners|Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst]] (today operating in Europe as [[Lion Capital LLP]]) for £2.14 billion/$3.5 billion,{{cite web|url=http://www.yellgroup.com/english/aboutyell-yelluk-yellukhistory-2000 |title=Yell History – 2000+ |publisher=Yell.com |accessdate=11 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208131527/http://www.yellgroup.com/english/aboutyell-yelluk-yellukhistory-2000 |archivedate=8 February 2008 |df=dmy-all }} making it then the largest non-corporate LBO in European history. ===2001–2011=== Yell bought [[McLeodUSA]], one of the largest independent directory publishers in the US for about $600 million in 2002,[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/1774061.stm Yell buys US directories] BBC News, 21 January 2002 and floated on London's [[FTSE 100 Index|FTSE]] in 2003.[http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/03_29/b3842142_mz035.htm Europe's IPO trickle could become a flood] Businessweek, 21 July 2003 In May 2005, Yell announced the acquisition of U.S. directory publisher TransWestern Publishing (and its holding company TransWestern Holdings L.P. from a consortium of private equity firms ([[Thomas H. Lee Partners]] and [[CIVC Partners]] for $1.575 billion (£829 million). TransWestern operated in 25 states and had core positions in California and Texas. The deal went through later in the year, making Yell's U.S. subsidiary Yellowbook the fifth largest directory publisher in the United States at that time.[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/7882912/ Yell Group to buy US phone book rival] MSNBC, 17 May 2005 TransWestern had been acquired by [[CIVC Partners]] in 1993 and was used as a vehicle for additional acquisitions of smaller directories publishers in the western US. In 1997, TransWestern completed a [[leveraged recapitalization|leveraged recapitalisation]] in which [[Thomas H. Lee Partners]] and [[Providence Equity Partners]] acquired a 60% interest in the company, with CIVC retaining a minority interest.[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-19727717.html TransWestern Publishing Company, L.P. Announces $300 Million Recapitalization with Thomas H. Lee Company]. 8 September 1997 In 2001, TransWestern acquired Texas-based WorldPages.com, Inc., a leading print and Internet yellow pages publisher listed on the [[New York Stock Exchange]] for $215 million. At the time, TransWestern was the second largest independent publisher of directories.[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_/ai_73703301 TransWestern Publishing to Acquire WorldPages.com; Creates Second-Largest Independent Telephone Directory Company with Strong Presence in Both Print and Online Markets]. Business Wire, 27 April 2001 In April 2006, Yell agreed to purchase a 59.9% stake in Spanish phone directory firm Telefónica Publicidad e Informacion (TPI) from [[Telefónica]], and launched a bid for the remaining shares which valued TPI at a total of {{GBP}}2.3 billion (€3.3 billion; US$4.1bn). Since then, Yell has bought further capital and in September 2007 reached agreement with the minority shareholders to acquire the remaining 1.28% of what was then named Yell Publicidad (now named Hibu Connect S.A.U., operating under the name Páginas Amarillas España).[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4953286.stm Yell snaps up Spanish rival TPI] BBC News, 28 April 2006 In July 2006, Yell threatened [[Yellowikis]] with legal action, claiming that people will confuse the two organisations.{{cite news| title =Legal threat to wiki listing site|work=BBC News | date = 12 July 2006| url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/5169674.stm| accessdate =12 July 2006}} In 2008, Yell Group purchased the Pindar Set business and renamed it Yell Adworks.[http://www.printweek.com/news/829640/Pindar-sell-directory-division-Yell/ Pindar sell directory division to Yell] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091019125838/http://www.printweek.com/news/829640/Pindar-sell-directory-division-Yell |date=19 October 2009 }} Print Week, 8 July 2008 In May 2009, Yell UK announced an alliance with [[Google]] to provide search marketing services to small businesses,[https://www.theguardian.com/media/pda/2009/may/14/yell-gives-up-google-competition-adwords Yell.com stops competing with Google, sell its adwords instead] guardian.co.uk, 14 May 2009 followed by Yell Publicidad in January 2010.[http://www.yellgroup.com/english/media-pressreleases-2010-yellpublicidadpaginasamarillassignsastrategic Yell Publicidad-Páginas Amarillas signs a strategic agreement to become an authorised reseller of Google's advertising offer in Spain] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720150126/http://www.yellgroup.com/english/media-pressreleases-2010-yellpublicidadpaginasamarillassignsastrategic |date=20 July 2011 }} Press Release 25 January 2010 In June 2009, Yell Group announced the appointment of [[Bob Wigley]] as Chairman, following the announcement in May 2009, that existing chairman Bob Scott would step down.[http://www.yellgroup.com/english/media-pressreleases-2009-appointmentofchairman Appointment of Chairman] Associates|Landor]].{{cite news|title=Yell surprises with change of name to Hibu|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/yell-surprises-with-change-of-name-to-hibu-7778853.html|work=Independent|accessdate=23 May 2012|date=23 May 2012|location=London}} The company's shareholders approved the change of name at its annual general meeting held on 27 July 2012, and the new name became effective from 30 July 2012.{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/07/26/yell-brief-idINWLA100120120726|title=Yell says received shareholders' approval to change name to Hibu|accessdate=7 August 2012|publisher=Reuters|date=26 July 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://uk.finance.yahoo.com/news/hibu-plc-change-name-hibu-070500194.html|title=hibu plc — Change of name to hibu plc|accessdate=7 August 2012|publisher=Yahoo! Finance|date=30 July 2012}} The company continued to acquire additional companies, with [[Moonfruit]], a DIY website company, purchased in May 2012 for £18m.{{cite web|last=Solon |first=Olivia |title=Yell snaps up DIY website and shop builder Moonfruit for £18m |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-05/16/moonfruit-acquired-by-yell |work=Wired |accessdate=23 May 2012 |date=16 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120519063049/http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-05/16/moonfruit-acquired-by-yell |archivedate=19 May 2012 |df= }} In September 2012, it warned that it is working with a number of capital options that which may attribute little or no value to the group’s ordinary shares, it also warned profits would miss forecasts owing to the ongoing decline of its directory business. As part of a strategic review of the business, in Spring 2014 Hibu decided to discontinue its US magazine business, having taken similar actions in the UK, Spain and Latin America. On 3 March 2014, Hibu announced that the financial restructuring of the group is now effective following consent from lenders, clearance from the UK Pensions Regulator and court sanction. All of Hibu’s operations were transferred to a new group holding company, held privately by lenders. On 18 August 2014,{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/yellow-pages-in-uturn-over-hibu-brand-9543137.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Gideon | last=Spanier | title=Yellow Pages in u-turn over Hibu brand | date=17 June 2014}} Hibu UK changed their customer facing brand back to Yell. They re-launched with an updated range of products including websites, pay-per-click advertising and a new display advertising proposition. As of June 2015, Yell has created over 54,000 websiteshttps://business.yell.com/websites/ and managed 20,000 [[Pay per click|PPC]] campaignshttps://business.yell.com/ppc/ for customers in the UK. ==Operations== The company operates in the classified advertising markets in the UK and US through digital, printed and telephone-based media. It is organised as follows: *[[Yell (company)|Yell UK]] *Hibu US ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://hibucorporate.com Official Corporate Website] {{BT Group}} {{Telecommunications industry in the United Kingdom}} {{Telephone directory publishers in the United States}} [[Category:Apax Partners companies]] [[Category:2001 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Companies based in Reading, Berkshire]] [[Category:Companies established in 2001]] [[Category:Companies formerly listed on the London Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Companies that have entered administration in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Private equity portfolio companies]] [[Category:Service companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Telephone directory publishing companies]] [[Category:Yellow pages]]

[[Image:HoustonMuseumDistrictSign.JPG|thumb|A direction sign in the Museum District]] [[File:Houston Museum District.jpg|thumb|Museum District Red Line southbound station]] [[Image:HoustonMuseumDistrict.jpg|thumb|Museum District Red Line northbound station]] The '''Houston Museum District''' is an association of 19 [[museum]]s, galleries, cultural centers and community organizations located in [[Houston]], [[Texas]], dedicated to promoting art, science, history and culture. The Houston Museum District currently includes 19 museums that recorded a collective attendance of over 8.7 million visitors a year.Visit Houston Website, https://www.visithoustontexas.com/about-houston/neighborhoods/museum-district/ All of the museums offer free times or days and 11 of the museums are free all the time.{{cite web |title=HMDA Fact Sheet |format=PDF |publisher=Houston Museum District Association |url=http://www.houstonmuseumdistrict.org/default/Fact%20Sheet%202008.doc |accessdate=2009-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719175047/http://www.houstonmuseumdistrict.org/default/Fact%20Sheet%202008.doc |archivedate=2011-07-19 |df= }} Thursdays the Museum District gets particularly crowded because of museum free days. On Thursdays, The Houston Museum of Natural Science is free after 2 p.m.,{{cite web|url=http://www.hmns.org/visit/hours-and-pricing/|title=Hours and Pricing - Houston Museum Of Natural Science|author=|date=|website=www.hmns.org}} The Children's Museum of Houston is free after 5 p.m.,{{cite web|url=http://www.cmhouston.org/freefamilynight|title=Free Family Night at Children's Museum of Houston|author=|date=|website=Children's Museum of Houston}} The Health Museum is free from 2-7,{{cite web|url=https://www.thehealthmuseum.org/content-page/plan-your-visit|title=Plan Your Visit - The Health Museum|author=|date=|website=www.thehealthmuseum.org}} and the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston is free all day (courtesy of Shell) .{{cite web|url=https://www.mfah.org/visit/hours-and-admissions/|title=Hours & Admissions - The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston|author=|date=|website=www.mfah.org}} Houston's Museum District is walkable and bikeable. Sidewalks are wide and well-maintained, and attractions and restaurants are situated near each other.{{cite web|url=https://www.visithoustontexas.com/about-houston/neighborhoods/museum-district/|title=Houston Museum District - About Houston's Neighborhoods|author=|date=|website=Visit Houston}} Bordered roughly by [[Texas State Highway 288]], [[Hermann Park]], [[U.S. Route 59]], and the [[Texas Medical Center]],Mulvaney, Erin. "[http://www.houstonchronicle.com/business/real-estate/article/Museum-District-becomes-a-place-of-contrasts-8348899.php Neighborhoods: Museum District becomes a place of contrasts]." ''[[Houston Chronicle]]''. July 8, 2016. Retrieved on July 11, 2016. the Museum District specifically refers to the area located within a 1.5-mile radius of the Mecom Fountain in [[Hermann Park]].{{cite web|title=About HMDA|url=http://houstonmuseumdistrict.org/about-hmda/|website=Houston Museum District Association|accessdate=18 September 2014}}{{failed verification|date=July 2016}} The Museum District Civic Association compared the area to [[Georgetown (Washington, D.C.)|Georgetown]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] and to the [[French Quarter]] of [[New Orleans]]. The Museum District is served by four stops on the [[METRORail]], one specifically named for it and is easily accessible from [[Interstate 69|I-69]]/[[U.S. Route 59|US 59]], [[Texas State Highway 288|State Highway 288]] and Main Street, across from the main entrance to Rice University. The beginnings of the Museum District are found in 1977, when it became apparent that some action needed to be taken to provide easier access to the museums of the area. This call for community improvement evolved into the non-profit Montrose Project by the mid-1980s but changed into the Museum District Development Association of Houston (MDDAH) shortly thereafter. Based on the works of this organization, the Museum District was formally recognized by the City of Houston in 1989. The founding organization was dissolved in 1994, but the Museum District is now under the auspices of the Houston Museum District Association, founded in 1997. The Museum District attracts visitors, students and volunteers of all ages, backgrounds, and ethnicities to learn about and celebrate art, history, culture, and nature around the world. More information on the 20 institutions of Houston's Museum District{{cite web|url=http://www.houstonmuseumdistrict.org|title=Houston Museum District|work=houmuse.org}} may be found on their official website. ==History== In the late 1970s, the area currently including the Houston Museum District had fallen into disrepair, badly needing attention from local, county and state governments to improve roads and beautify the area, then unsafe for pedestrian traffic and cyclists. The Houston Museum District began as a grassroots community movement in 1977 led by Alexandra R. Marshall whose concept was to create a pedestrian-friendly district with the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Houston|Museum of Fine Arts]], at the intersection of Bissonnet Street and Montrose Boulevard, as its core. In such a strongly vehicle-oriented city, and one which to this day retains the title of the largest city in the [[United States of America|United States]] without [[zoning]], this was fairly progressive. The Museum District Development Association of Houston proposed a multi-phase plan to beautify and make more pedestrian-friendly the area located between [[Allen Parkway]], [[Buffalo Bayou]] and Hermann Park. It took advantage of the opportunity to create in Houston an area of vital urban importance, similar to the [[French Quarter]] in [[New Orleans]], [[Boulevard Saint-Germain|St. Germain]] in [[Paris]], and [[Georgetown, Washington, D.C.|Georgetown]] in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington, DC]]. Since its creation, the numerous efforts of the Houston Museum District organizations have included community improvement projects, tree planting, sidewalk planning, construction and expansion, esplanade design, development and beautification, establishment of public transportation to and from the area, police support and various cultural events The Montrose Association, the Museum Area Municipal Association, the South Main Civic Association, the Cultural Arts Center of Houston and TALA (Texas Accountants and Lawyers for the Arts) all played a part in the development and subsequent success in the creation of the Houston Museum District. ===Timeline=== *'''1977:''' Concept formulated, area associations involved. *'''January 1986:''' Montrose Project incorporated.{{cite web |title= Acceptance of Montrose Project Articles of Incorporation |format=PDF |publisher = Houston Museum District Association | url = http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:ArticlesOfIncorporationMontroseProject.pdf | accessdate = 2009-11-05}} *'''July 1986:''' Montrose Project becomes the Museum District Development Association of Houston.{{cite web |title= HMDDA Acceptance of Articles of Incorporation |format=PDF |publisher = Houston Museum District Association | url = http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:HoustonMuseumDistrictArticlesOfIncorperation.pdf | accessdate = 2009-11-05}} *'''March 1987:''' MDDAH gains [[501(c)| 501(c)3]] status.{{cite web |title=501(c)3 Approval |format=PDF |publisher = Houston Museum District Association | url = http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:HMDDA501c3Status.pdf | accessdate = 2009-11-05}} *'''May 1988:''' “Raiders of the Lost Art” event held to raise funds and awareness of the District.{{cite web |title=Raiders of the Lost Art Program |format=PDF |publisher = Houston Museum District Association | url = http://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:HoustonMuseumDistrictRaidersOfTheLostArt1of2.pdf | accessdate = 2009-11-06}} [[Image:MDDResolution.png|thumb|City of Houston Museum District Resolution]] *'''September 1989:''' The Museum District receives a Clean Houston Honorable Mention in the Proud Partners Awards for its Museum District Improvement program.{{cite web |title= Museum District Clean Houston Award |format=PDF |publisher = Houston Museum District Association | url = http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:MDDAHCleanHoustonAward.pdf | accessdate = 2009-11-06}} *'''September 1989:''' Business leaders, museum directors and members gathered to sign a coalition agreement supporting a City of Houston Resolution creating an official Museum District.{{cite web |title= Museum District Coalition Agreement |format=PDF |publisher = Houston Museum District Association | url = http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:HoustonMuseumDistrictCoalitionAgreement.pdf | accessdate = 2009-11-05}} *'''October 18, 1989:''' The area along Montrose Boulevard, from Allen Parkway to Hermann Park was designated by the City of Houston City Council and [[Kathryn J. Whitmire|Mayor Kathryn Whitmire]] as the official Museum District of Houston. *'''1990:''' The Cultural Arts Council of Houston, now known as Houston Arts Alliance published ''The Cultural Guide to Houston'', a guide book of Houston which included maps of each cultural center in the city, including a map of the Museum District. *'''December 1991:''' MDDAH helped host the 5th Annual Christmas and Hanukkah in Neartown, with a tree lighting, caroling and a Children’s Parade and Festival. *'''May 1992:''' “Savor the Flavors” benefit held for the Museum District, highlighting 23 local restaurants. *'''1994:''' The organized abandonment/dissolution of the 501(c)3 Museum District Development Association of Houston. Records were handed off to the South Main Center Association for further collaboration and development within the community. *'''November 1996:''' Shepherded by the South Main Center Association, now South Main Alliance, the organizations of the Museum District joined together to publish a brochure, promoting the Museum District, which included new member museums. *'''January 1997:''' Eleven institutions reincorporated the Houston Museum District Association as a 501(c)3 corporation.
