'''Vector tiles''', '''tiled vectors''' or '''vectiles'''{{cite web|url=http://mike.teczno.com/notes/postgreslessness-mapnik-vectiles.html|title=the liberty of postgreslessness: tiled vectors in mapnik (tecznotes)|publisher=mike.teczno.com|accessdate=2014-08-24}} are packets of geographic data, packaged into pre-defined roughly-square shaped "tiles" for transfer over the web. This is an emerging method for delivering styled [[Web mapping|web maps]], combining certain benefits of pre-rendered raster map tiles with [[vector map]] data. As with the widely used raster [[tiled web map]]s, map data is requested by a client as a set of "tiles" corresponding to square areas of land of a pre-defined size and location. Unlike raster tiled web maps, however, the server returns vector map data, which has been clipped to the boundaries of each tile, instead of a pre-rendered map image. There are several major advantages of this hybrid approach. Compared to an un-tiled vector map, the data transfer is reduced,{{cite web|url=http://research.microsoft.com/en-us/um/redmond/projects/mapcruncher/TiledVectors/TiledVectorsDemo-1.1/description.html|title=About Tiled Vectors|publisher=research.microsoft.com|accessdate=2014-08-24}} because only data within the current viewport, and at the current zoom level needs to be transferred. The [[geographic information system|GIS]] clipping operations can all be performed in advance, as the tile boundaries are pre-defined. This in turn means that tiled vector data can be packaged up and distributed, without needing any kind of GIS system available to serve data. Compared to a tiled raster map, data transfer is also greatly reduced, as vector data is typically much smaller than a rendered bitmap. Also, styling can be applied later in the process, or even in the browser itself, allowing much greater flexibility in how data is presented. It is also easy to provide interactivity with map features, as their vector representation already exists within the client. Yet another benefit is that less centralised server processing power is required, since rasterisation can be performed directly in the client. This has been described as making "rendering ... a last-mile problem, with fast, high-quality GPU[s] in everyone’s pocket".{{Cite web|url = http://mike.teczno.com/img/Geomeetup-slides-2013-04.pdf|title = Geomeetup Slides 2013-04|date = 2013-04-01|accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = Migurski|first = Michal}} == History == There is a long history of the use of vector tile schemes in GIS. A very early GIS (circa 1966), the Canada Geographic Information System (CGIS), used a vector tile storage scheme that allowed limited resource computers to efficiently access and process vector map data.{{Cite web|url=https://www.crcpress.com/Introductory-Readings-In-Geographic-Information-Systems/Peuquet-Marble/9780203393246|title=Introductory Readings In Geographic Information Systems|website=CRC Press|access-date=2016-04-26}} CGIS used the term "frame" instead of vector tiles. In 1975, the US Wildlife Service initiated a national program to map and digitize all the wetlands in the US. In 1976 they awarded a contract to Autometric to develop a software application that allowed stereo imagery to be digitized using an analytical stereo plotter. Later support for 2d digitization from single photos (aka single photo resection) on a digitizing table was added. The software was called WAMS (Wetlands Analytical Mapping System). The WAMS data store used a tiled vector structure. Each tile was called a “geounit”. A geounit corresponded to one of the USGS quadrangle scales, typically 1:24000. As the data were digitized, they were immediately stored in the tiled data store and topologically structured. Lines crossing geounit boundaries were automatically split. The storage Coordinate Reference System (CRS) was WGS 72 lat/long. WAMS is described in detail in “The wetlands analytical mapping system: WAMS" [Pywell and Niedzwiadek, 1980] Building on the operational experience gained in implementing and using WAMS as well as from the Map Overlay and Statistical System (MOSS),Moss: A Historical Perspective https://www.scribd.com/document/4606038/2004-Article-by-Carl-Reed-MOSS-A-Historical-perspective in 1986 Autometric released a UNIX based commercial GIS that implemented an enhanced vector tile storage and access structure: DeltaMap (later GenaMap). The vector tile structure and capability is described in "DeltaMap: Not just another GIS".Reed C N (1986) DELTAMAP: Not just another new GIS- Proceedings of the 3rd International Symposium on Spatial Data Handling. IGU Commission on Geographical Data Sensing and Processing, Williamsville NY, pp. 375-83 Where WAMS implemented a fixed tile system based on latitude/longitude 1:24000 quadrangles, DeltaMap allowed the user to define any size tile in any coordinate reference system (CRS). In this way, sparse data required only a few tiles whereas dense data could use much smaller tiles. R-trees were used as the indexing scheme for the vector tiles. In the late 1980's, Genasys further enhanced GenaMap to allow "Continuous, seamless" processing of the tiled layers. Basically, from the end user perspective, the tiles became invisible. This capability was true regardless of whether the user were editing, visualizing, querying, or analyzing the data. == Standards and approaches == As of early 2015, there is no dominant standard for vector tiles. Approaches can differ in their URL format, data serialisation format, packaging of styling information, and support for projections other than Web Mercator. === Protocol buffers (Mapbox) === [[Mapbox]] has defined an open standard for vector map tiles called "vector-tile-spec" which uses [[Google Protocol Buffers|Google protocol buffers]] for space-efficient data serialisation. [[Web Mercator]] is the projection of reference, but vector tiles may be used to represent data with any projection and tile extent scheme.{{cite web|url=https://github.com/mapbox/vector-tile-spec/tree/master/2.1|title=vector-tile-spec/2.1 at master · mapbox/vector-tile-spec · GitHub|publisher=github.com|accessdate=2016-05-24}} It is also tied to the [[Mapnik]] rendering engine, using a "serialized version of the internal data that Mapnik uses".{{Cite web|url = https://www.mapbox.com/developers/vector-tiles/|title = Vector Tiles Overview|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = Mapbox|last = |first = }} In March 2015, [[Esri]], the dominant geospatial software maker, announced that they would be supporting Mapbox's vector tiles standard in both server and client platforms.{{Cite web|url = https://www.mapbox.com/blog/vector-tile-adoption/|title = Mapbox Vector Tile Specification adopted by Esri|date = 2015-03-17|accessdate = |website = Mapbox blog|publisher = |last = |first = }} === Mapnik Vector Tile === This was an early format developed for the Mapnik renderer.{{Cite web|title = Python: module TileStache.Goodies.VecTiles.mvt|url = http://tilestache.org/doc/TileStache.Goodies.VecTiles.mvt.html|website = tilestache.org|accessdate = 2015-11-20}} === Other formats === The approach followed by TileStache is to allow multiple data serialisation formats; as of early 2015, it supports GeoJSON, ArcJSON, GeoBSON, Arc GeoServices BSON, GeoAMF and Arc GeoServices BSON. The requested format is given in the URL (e.g., http://example.com/tiles/mylayer/2/1/3.json) ==Support== === Services and applications === Vector tiles have been used by the Google Maps Android client since December 2010{{cite web|url=http://googlemobile.blogspot.com.au/2010/12/under-hood-of-google-maps-50-for.html|title=Under the hood of Google Maps 5.0 for Android - Official Google Mobile Blog|publisher=googlemobile.blogspot.com.au|accessdate=2014-08-24}} and on the desktop client since 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/05/15/redesigned-google-maps-hands-on-io-2013/|title=Redesigned Google Maps hands-on: vector-based, more personal and coming soon to mobile|publisher=engadget.com|accessdate=2014-08-24}} Vector tiles for rendering OpenStreetMap data were first proposed in March 2013 and are supported by Mapnik,{{cite web|url=https://github.com/mapbox/mapnik-vector-tile|title=mapbox/mapnik-vector-tile · GitHub|publisher=github.com|accessdate=2014-08-24}} the most widely used renderer of OpenStreetMap data. [[Mapbox]], a commercial provider of custom cartography tools and hosting, has focused its cartography tool, Mapbox Studio, around vector tiles.{{cite web|url=https://www.mapbox.com/blog/vector-tiles/|title=Vector Tiles for MapBox Streets | Mapbox|publisher=mapbox.com|accessdate=2014-08-24}} The popular, and very powerful, Android client for OpenStreetMap data, [[osmAnd]] supports vector tiles, which it calls "vector maps".{{cite web|url=https://code.google.com/p/osmand/wiki/HowToVectorTileData|title=HowToVectorTileData - osmand - This article describes how to use key features - Global Mobile Map Viewing & Navigation for Offline and Online OSM Maps - Google Project Hosting|publisher=code.google.com|accessdate=2014-08-24}} === Servers === The tile server pipeline [[TileStache]] supports several flavours of JSON natively.{{Cite web|url = http://tilestache.org/doc/TileStache.Vector.html|title = TileStache.Vector|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} There is also a plugin vector tile provider called VecTiles{{Cite web|url = http://tilestache.org/doc/TileStache.Goodies.VecTiles.server.html#Provider%20-%20MVT%20or%20GeoJSON|title = TileStache.Goodies.VecTiles.server|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} which converts PostGIS data into vector tiles in Mapnik Vector Tile format (incompatible with the Mapbox specification{{Cite web|title = Protobuf.skip unimplemented types · Issue #15 · SpatialServer/Leaflet.MapboxVectorTile|url = https://github.com/SpatialServer/Leaflet.MapboxVectorTile/issues/15|website = GitHub|accessdate = 2015-11-20}}) or [[TopoJSON]]. PGRestAPI (also known as Chubbs Spatial Server) is a standalone NodeJS server which can also generate vector tiles on the fly from a PostGIS data source, as well as serving pre-generated vector tiles from sources such as Mapbox Studio.{{Cite web|url = https://github.com/spatialdev/PGRestAPI|title = PGRestAPI (aka Chubbs Spatial Server)|date = 2015-02-25|accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} ESRI ArcGIS Server 10.4https://blogs.esri.com/esri/arcgis/2016/02/18/arcgis-10-4-is-here/ and ArcGIS Pro 1.2https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/get-started/whats-new-in-arcgis-pro-1-2.htm released in February 2016 added support for vector tiles. === Client libraries === The Leaflet JavaScript library does not directly support vector tiles, but there are third-party plugin for vector tiles, Leaflet.MapboxVectorTile for Leaflet 0.7.x{{Cite web|url = https://github.com/SpatialServer/Leaflet.MapboxVectorTile|title = Leaflet.MapboxVectorTile|date = 2015-02-12|accessdate = |website = GitHub|publisher = |last = |first = }} and Leaflet.VectorGrid for Leaflet 1.0.x.{{Cite web|url = https://github.com/Leaflet/Leaflet.VectorGrid|title = Leaflet.VectorGrid|date = 2017-02-16|accessdate = |website = GitHub|publisher = |last = |first = }} Mapbox's own JavaScript library, Mapbox.js, can be used.{{Cite web|url = https://www.mapbox.com/mapbox.js|title = API Documentation|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = Mapbox|last = |first = }} OpenLayers supports vector tiles through the ol.source.VectorTile object,{{Cite web|url = http://openlayers.org/en/latest/apidoc/ol.source.VectorTile.html|title = Open Layers 3 documentation|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} as of version 3. == External links == * [[openstreetmap:Vector tiles|Vector tiles (OpenStreetMap wiki)]] * [https://openmaptiles.org/ OpenMapTiles project] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Web mapping]] [[Category:Google Maps]] [[Category:OpenStreetMap]]

page.title: View on the Amstel from Amsteldijk

revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | image_file = SA 56435-Gezicht op Amsterdam vanaf de Amsteldijk.jpg | caption = | painting_alignment = | image_size = 300px | title = View on the Amstel from Amsteldijk | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Jacob van Ruisdael]] | year = 1680 | material = | height_metric = 53.4 | width_metric = 67.6 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = cm<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default cm. Not including it will default it to cm.--> | imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. Not including it will default it to in.--> | city = [[Amsterdam]] | museum = [[Amsterdam Museum]] | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = |url=[http://hdl.handle.net/11259/collection.67437 Amsterdam Collection online] }} '''''View on the Amstel from Amsteldijk''''' (c. 1680) is an [[oil painting|oil]] on canvas painting by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] landscape painter [[Jacob van Ruisdael]]. It is an example of [[Dutch Golden Age painting]] and is now in the collection of the [[Amsterdam Museum]].
This painting was purchased in 2007 with support from the [[Vereniging Rembrandt]] as an important artifact of [[Amsterdam]] history.<ref>[http://www.verenigingrembrandt.nl/152/de-kunst/gesteunde-kunst/gezicht-op-amsterdam-vanaf-de-amsteldijk Information] on Vereniging Rembrandt website</ref> It was documented by [[Hofstede de Groot]] in 1911, who wrote; "17. View of Amsterdam. The [[Amstel]] fills the right-hand side of the picture. In the centre is a canal bordered by a meadow. A ray of light illumines the town. In the sky are masses of storm-cloud. Canvas. Sale. [[Charles de Morny, Duke of Morny|Comte de Morny]], Paris, May 24, 1852, No. 24 (3100 francs)."<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn04hofsuoft#page/13/mode/1up Entry 17 for ''''View of Amsterdam''] in Hofstede de Groot, 1911</ref>
According to Vereniging Rembrandt, the steeples in this painting are from left to right: [[Leidsepoort]], [[Utrechtsepoort]], [[Westerkerk]], [[Stadhuis (Dam)]], [[Oude Kerk, Amsterdam|Oude Kerk]], [[Zuiderkerk]], [[Portugees-Joodse Synagoge]], [[Nederlands Scheepvaartmuseum|'s Lands zeemagazijn]], [[Weesperpoort]], [[Oosterkerk]]. All of these buildings had been recently designed and built under the supervision of the city architect [[Daniël Stalpaert]].
This scene is very similar to other paintings Ruisdael made in this period of Amsterdam and these often served as inspiration for later painters of landscape. <gallery> File:Jacob van Ruisdael - A view of Amsterdam 1665-1670.jpg|[[National Gallery]]. File:Jacob van Ruisdael - View on the Amstel Looking towards Amsterdam.jpg|[[Fitzwilliam Museum]]. File:Jacob van Ruisdael Vue d'Amsterdam.jpg|[[Museum of Fine Arts (Budapest)]]. </gallery>

{{Use British English|date=December 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} [[Keith Floyd]] (1943–2009) was an English broadcaster, restaurateur and food writer. He was brought up in [[Somerset]], England, where his mother taught him to cook.{{sfn|Levy|2013}} He was educated at [[Wellington School, Somerset|Wellington]], a local [[Public school (United Kingdom)|public school]], although he left at the age of sixteen. He joined the ''[[Bristol Evening Post]]'' as a cub reporter—where he worked alongside the future playwright [[Tom Stoppard]]. He was commissioned into the [[Royal Tank Regiment]] in 1963 as a [[second lieutenant]], but his career there only lasted until 1966; he left military service and moved to London and then France, where he worked in several restaurants in various roles.{{sfn|Levy|2013}} In 1971 he set up his first restaurant in [[Bristol]]—Floyd's Bistro—which proved popular enough for him to open three further outlets in the city. His burgeoning empire soon collapsed and he sailed around the [[Mediterranean]] for two years, from where he exported wine to the UK. He also opened a restaurant in the south of France, but this was also unsuccessful and it closed in 1979, when Floyd returned to the UK.{{sfn|Levy|2013}} He opened another Bristol-based restaurant and wrote a book—''Floyd's Food''—which was locally published in 1981; this led to a short recipe slot on the local [[Heart Bristol|Radio West]] station. In 1983 one of his customers—David Pritchard, a television producer—suggested to Floyd that he front a television series, which resulted in ''Floyd on Fish'', broadcast on [[BBC Two]] in late 1985.{{sfn|Levy|2013}} Several series followed on the BBC before the Floyd-Pritchard partnership broke up in 1993; a corresponding book appeared with each series.{{sfn|Levy|2013}} There were no scripts for the programmes, and Floyd [[Ad libitum|ad-libbed]] throughout; when he ran out of words, he would sip from an ever-present glass of wine to give him time to create the next line. Pritchard's directing style and Floyd's presentation technique produced what the food writer [[Tom Jaine]] considers as "cheerful mayhem", although viewers were educated in basic techniques. He went on to say that "Floyd's performances, on or near the stove, were a refreshing departure from the prissy, controlled style then in favour at the BBC, or the alternative mode of half an hour with a French chef whose incomprehensible English made the recipes a mystery." Paul Levy, Floyd's obituarist, considered the broadcaster had "no outstanding talent, either as a cook or as a TV presenter, no great knowledge of his subject, or any apparent passion for anything but drink. This is not to say that his first TV programmes were bad – they were, indeed, highly diverting entertainment". The programmes were also highly popular both with the public and other cooks. Following his death of heart disease in September 2009 several fellow chefs voiced their opinions of him. [[Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall]] considers that Floyd "cooked his ingredients with the love and passion of a gifted amateur", while [[Heston Blumenthal]] opines that "His enthusiasm, even when he was being a bit crotchety, jumped out of the screen. No-one made TV food programmes quite like him. He had a wealth of knowledge but there was a no-nonsense approach to it all". ==Bibliography== ===Food and drink writing=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="margin-right: 0;" |+ Floyd's food and drink bibliography |- ! scope="col" | Title{{sfn|Howard|2007|p=79}} ! scope="col" | Year of first

{{Infobox company | name = ''ZUMA Press'' | logo = Zuma Press Logo.jpg | type = | location_city = [[San Clemente]], [[California]] | location_country = [[United States]] | key_people = Scott McKiernan, Founder and [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] | area_served = [[World]]wide | industry = [[News media]] | products = [[Wire service]], [[Photography]] | members = | num_employees = | homepage ={{URL|www.zumapress.com}} }} '''ZUMA Press''' is an independent press agency and [[News agency|wire service]].{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} It was founded in 1993 by photojournalist Scott McKiernan, with a global staff of over 50, covering over 100 news, sports, and entertainment events worldwide.<ref name="zumapress.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.zumapress.com|title=ZUMA Press|website=www.zumapress.com}}</ref>
The agency represents more than 2,100 photographers as well as a collection of over 100 [[newspaper]] archives worldwide including those of ''[[Daily Mail]],'' ''[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]],'' ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' (London), ''[[Toronto Star]],'' ''[[Los Angeles Daily News]],'' ''[[San Antonio Express-News]],'' ''[[Sacramento Bee]],'' ''[[St. Petersburg Times]],'' and ''[[Palm Beach Post]].'' The company also represents picture agencies Action Images, [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur|DPA]], [[EFE]], [[European Pressphoto Agency|EPA]], and [[Gamma (agency)|Gamma]].
The company,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.poyi.org/65/winnerslist.html|title=Winners List - Sixty-Fifth Pictures of the Year International Competition|publisher=[[Pictures of the Year International]]}}</ref> its photographers<ref name="poyi.org">{{cite web|url=http://poyi.org/66/66winnerslist.html|title=Winners List - Sixty-Sixth Pictures of the Year International Competition|publisher=[[Pictures of the Year International]]}}</ref><ref name="poyi-64">{{cite web|url=http://www.poyi.org/64/winnerslist.html|title=Winners of the Sixty-Fourth Annual: Pictures of the Year International Competition: Judged February 18 through March 8, 2007 |publisher=[[Pictures of the Year International]]}}</ref> and its ''DOUBLEtruck'' magazine<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.poyi.org/63/winnerslist.html|title=Winners of the Sixty-Third Annual: Pictures of the Year International Competition: Judged February 19 through March 8, 2006 n|publisher=[[Pictures of the Year International]]}}</ref> have received awards including those from [[Pictures of the Year International]]<ref name="poyi.org"/> and [[World Press Photo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldpressphoto.org/index.php?option=com_photogallery&task=view&id=1423&Itemid=224&bandwidth=high|title=World Press Photo|website=World Press Photo}}</ref>
ZUMA is headquartered in [[San Clemente]], [[California]], with major bureaus in Hollywood, London and New York, as well as other locations worldwide.
